title: anyone can see no ones obeying covid rules anymore
story: You can see it all around you: people disappearing into other people’s houses, without even a furtive glance to see if anyone is watching large groups gathering in defiance of the ‘rule of six’, or perhaps ignorance that it is still in place. People who earlier in the year were studiously following the rules are now breaking them in all kinds of little ways. The public has decided that the Covid emergency is over – at least for now – and are regaining their lives by stealth.By refusing to open up sooner, the government is losing its control of the population. But then was it ever really in control anyway? No doubt Matt Hancock, along with some of the Cabinet’s other native authoritarians, takes personal credit for tackling the Covid crisis by forcing people to socially-distance. Yet evidence points elsewhere: to the public leading the government in efforts to combat the pandemic, not the other way around. Some government advisers have taken to claiming that thousands of lives could have been saved had lockdown been imposed a week earlier than 23 March last year, the day a solemn Boris Johnson told us all to stay at home. But it is a pretty irrelevant argument given that the public had already largely placed itself in self-imposed lockdown.By the following Monday, when the government’s tone changed after the publication of the famous Imperial paper predicting up to 500,000 deaths form Covid, tube usage had already plunged to 60 per cent. By that Friday it had fallen to just 24 per cent as employers and employees between them made voluntary arrangements to work at home, and by the following Monday, ahead of Johnson’s evening address to the nation, it had plummeted to only 15 per cent. By the time lockdown was imposed, in other words, there wasn’t much left to lock down.Just as the public led the government into lockdown, so it is leading the government out of lockdown. Last weekend, car traffic was back up to 96 per cent of pre-pandemic levels – in spite of messages which still flicker, pointlessly, from motorway gantries telling us to “minimise travel”. Light commercial traffic is 14 per cent higher than it was before the pandemic.Those of us who have stood against endless lockdowns, and the petty laws and eyewatering fines used to try to enforce them, have been accused in some quarters of irresponsibility. Yet all we have been doing is appealing for the government to trust our own sense of responsibility rather than try to steamroller us into compliance. With some exceptions, people have shown themselves perfectly able to make their own, reasoned assessment of the risks posed by Covid, and of acting accordingly.The government’s input has been to tie up that process in regulatory knots, ending with bizarre legal debates as to whether a Scotch egg counts as a substantial meal and so on.There are serious dangers from trying to command the public into how to behave. As well as creating the bad feeling which surrounds any illiberal regime, living under endless orders blunts our sense of personal responsibility. Just look how some people rushed out to the pub in the few days before the second lockdown came into effect in November. The last chance to do something legally had encouraged them to take risks they wouldn’t have taken had they been left to themselves to decide what was and what wasn’t safe.There is little purpose to the remaining restrictions on our day to day lives. People can see that the vaccination programme has been a brilliant success and that their risk of coming to serious harm from Covid is now no higher than of succumbing to other diseases. They no longer see why their lives should be put on hold. It is about time the government caught up.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: britain us pledge preserve freedom seas huge operation indo
story: Britain and America's navy chiefs said they were operating in lockstep to preserve the freedom of the seas as they met in Washington on Tuesday before a massive joint deployment to the Indo-Pacific region.The UK's First Sea Lord, Admiral Tony Radakin, said the deployment of the new Carrier Strike Group (CSG) was a testament to the strength of the special relationship in an increasingly contested world, as well as a recognition of the economic advantages of the region.The programme represents the UK's biggest deployment of maritime and air power since the Falklands war.Adml Radakin said Britain plans to increase its naval presence in the Indo-Pacific region in the wake of the recent integrated defence and security review.The defence review, which was published in March, identified China and Russia as two key global adversaries.We see China as being a challenge and a competitor, Adml Radakin told reporters at Washington's Navy Yard on Wednesday. I think when we talk about a tilt to the Indo-Pacific, it's about recognising the economic weight here. By 2040 to 2050, 40 per cent of the world's GDP is going to be harbored in that region.This amazing thing called the high seas, this global commons, which allows trade and prosperity to flourish, that exists all around the world. The Indo-Pacific is a crucial part of that. And therefore, we will look to signal our belief in the freedom of the high seas, and in a free and open Indo-Pacific.Read more: Defence review 2021: ‘Warhorses’ of the military put out to pasture as new era of fighting technology arrivesThe two-day visit is the first in-person event between Adml Radakin and his American counterpart, Admiral Mike Gilday, under the Biden administration.It comes as HMS Queen Elizabeth aircraft carrier begins its maiden deployment to the Indo-Pacific region this month, joined by a US Destroyer, USS The Sullivans, and a detachment of US Marine Corps F-35B Lightning II aircraft.The deployment to the Asia-Pacific region will see the CSG travel more than 26,000 nautical miles over 28 weeks.The CSG will visit 40 countries as part of the journey.HMS Queen Elizabeth will also sail through the South China Sea, which Beijing has become increasingly assertive over in recent years, on her way up to Japan for the final section of the trip.However, she is not expected to sail through the Taiwan Strait, which China would see as a provocation.Adml Radakin said Britain's tilt to the Indo-Pacific region included having a littoral-ready group operating at the western end of the Indian Ocean as well as reaching further East while building relationships with the Five Powers Defence Arrangements.However the First Sea Lord said the UK would also continue to be strong in the Euro-Atlantic as well as maintaining its naval responsibilities in other parts of the globe.Read more: HMS Queen Elizabeth: Britain's flagship aircraft carrier - from conception to deploymentMore from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: end pandering sinn fein ira
story: Even by the brutal standards of the IRA’s terrorist campaign against the British security forces during the Troubles, Joe McCann, the gunman killed by paratroopers in 1972, had acquired a reputation as one of the organisation’s most ruthless killers.Jailed as a teenager after being found in possession of five bayonets in the 1960s long before Northern Ireland was consumed by sectarian violence, McCann quickly rose to become a senior IRA commander in Belfast.In this role, his unwavering support for the “armed struggle”, as he called it, saw him responsible for the murder of at least 10 British soldiers, as well as the attempted assassination of the Ulster Unionist politician John Taylor in February 1972.McCann’s insatiable appetite for acts of extreme violence led to him being top of the Royal Ulster Constabulary’s wanted list. Indeed, it has even been suggested that his violent conduct prompted more moderate figures in the IRA leadership to reveal his whereabouts in Belfast, resulting in his killing by British soldiers in April 1972.It is a supreme irony, therefore, that one of the IRA’s more renowned killers should now, nearly 50 years after he met his violent end, be feted as a cause celebre by the republicans, someone who, instead of being remembered for the catalogue of violence he wrought, is lauded as an innocent victim of British brutality.The fact that McCann is viewed in such terms is the by-product of both the republican movement’s success in being able to see dubious cases relating to the Troubles brought to court, and the failure of successive British governments to prevent them from doing so.There have been numerous pledges in Queen’s Speeches dating back a decade or more in which ministers have pledged to address the anomaly by which veterans who risked their lives in the service of their country during the Troubles find themselves liable to prosecution, while IRA terrorists responsible for some of the worst atrocities of the era have been granted immunity.The fundamental reason for this iniquitous state of affairs dates back to the Good Friday Agreement in 1998, when Tony Blair, in his desperation to win republican support for the deal, in effect granted an amnesty to IRA terrorists, irrespective of the crimes they had committed. Mr Blair has subsequently argued that, without this concession, the deal would never have been struck.But it resulted in an estimated 200 “on-the-run” terrorists being sent letters providing assurances that they were no longer wanted by the police for their crimes. Among them was John Downey, who was accused of carrying out the 1982 Hyde Park bombing, which killed 11 soldiers.While legions of IRA terrorists have been granted immunity from prosecution, it is a disgrace that no provision has been made to give similar protection to British service personnel who served during the Troubles, even though prime ministers from David Cameron through to Boris Johnson have promised to do so.There is an expectation that a pledge to provide better protection to veterans will be contained in next week’s Queen’s Speech outlining the Government’s goals. The concern, though, is that, as with previous promises, no effective action will ultimately be forthcoming.The simple reason for the Government’s reluctance to act is that, by affording veterans the same immunity from prosecution as IRA terrorists, Downing Street risks alienating Sinn Fein, the current standard-bearers of the republican cause whose support is deemed essential to maintaining the peace in Northern Ireland.Consequently, while the British authorities are prevented from prosecuting those responsible for some of the worst atrocities during the Troubles, Sinn Fein and their allies in Northern Ireland can persist with their persecution of British veterans even when, as this week’s collapse of the trial of the two paratroopers accused of murdering McCann has graphically demonstrated, the evidence is deeply flawed.Even though legal experts had given explicit warnings that there were serious flaws in the prosecution case several years ago, Barra McGrory, Northern Ireland’s then director of public prosecutions, insisted on proceeding.Mr McGrory has previously represented Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams and his colleague Martin McGuinness, who are both alleged to have enjoyed close ties with the IRA. This has led to accusations that the trial of the two paratroopers was politically motivated, rather than an exercise in seeking justice.Certainly, with prosecutors in Northern Ireland said to be looking at pressing charges in another 200 cases involving veterans of the Troubles, there is an urgent need for the Government to take action to prevent further gross miscarriages of justice, instead of constantly pandering to the whims of Sinn Fein and its IRA supporters.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: sending ships france might stunt good one
story: To most of us, there is nothing wrong whatsoever with a PM standing up for Britain. Johnson’s front-foot approach to the Brexit negotiations, compared to Theresa May’s woeful timidity, is part of what made him so popular in the first place and delivered him that landslide majority in December 2019.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: keir starmer fork road labour
story: NewsopinionKeir Starmer: We are at a fork in the road - with Labour things can be betterEXCLUSIVE: Labour’s priorities are your priorities. But the Conservatives’ priorities are their friends and those on their WhatsApp groups, the Labour leader writes for the MirrormirrorShareCommentsByKeir Starmer:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionKeir Starmer said the Tories priorities are with their friends as he urged voters to back Labour at the polls " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThursdayaposs elections are a chance to vote for a brighter, better future for you, your family and your community. Where Labour is in power across the country, we are delivering. Our mayors and councillors are creating jobs, tackling crime and protecting the NHS despite cuts from Tories at Westminster. Labour’s priorities are your priorities. But the Conservatives’ priorities are their friends and those on their WhatsApp groups. Whether itaposs bending tax rules for those who have the Prime Minister’s phone number, handing out contracts to their mates, or wasting your money on contracts that don’t deliver, it’s one rule for them, another for the rest of us. I’m driven by a burning desire to make this country the best place to grow up in and the best place to grow old in, whoever you are and wherever you live.  First, we need to rethink our economy. For too long it has been based on short-term s, low wages and job insecurity. Leading business figures share our view that it needn’t be this way. Labour will ensure there are well paid jobs to be proud of all across the country, so we can get Britain working. Second, we’d invest in public services. As the most senior prosecutor in the country, I saw people coming through the criminal justice system who with earlier support wouldn’t have been there. Education, housing and mental health services cannot be slashed without consequences. We must rethink what we value. Third, a world-class education for every child, wherever they’re from. I want all our children to have every opportunity to achieve. I want them to be skilled, confident and ready to seize the possibilities of the future.

title: local election results timings hour
story: NewsLocal election results timings: Hour-by-hour guide to when key battles will be announcedThe Super Thursday local elections are the biggest for years and have a baffling array of council, parliament, mayor and police contests. So what are the ones to watch and how on earth will you keep up  Were here to take you throughmirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY NewsThese elections are largely local - but theyre a major first test for Boris Johnson and Keir Starmer" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeMillions of Brits have been voting today for  councils,  police commissioners,  mayors, two national parliaments, the London Assembly and the Hartlepool by-election.The ‘Super Thursday’ elections are the first ballot box test of Boris Johnson and Keir Starmer since the pandemic - with all eyes on the by-election which polls are tipping the Tories to take.The elections will also decide whether Labour have to rule in coalition in Wales, and whether Nicola Sturgeon gets the SNP majority she craves - allowing her a fresh push for Scottish independence. Most important perhaps are the thousands of power struggles at local council level that will never make national headline news. Results will start appearing in the early hours of Friday, but counting is slower than usual due to Covid restrictions and the number of dferent elections - up to four or five in some areas. It’s thought the full picture may not be known until late in the weekend or Monday. So with this labyrinth of results, how on earth are you supposed to keep up and interpret it all  Hereaposs our hour-by-hour guide breaking things down into manageable chunks. With thanks to PA Media and the Local Government Information Unit for parts of the information. Timings are only approximate estimates and could y wildly!  ENGLISH COUNCILS: More than , seats are up for grabs on  county,  unitary,  metropolitan and  district councils in England. Some are electing the whole council, some half their councillors and some only a third. Conservatives are defending slightly more seats while Labour are defending slightly more councils in control. But the Tories made big gains in , the last time many of these same seats were up for grabs - so Labour should be regaining this time. Boris Johnson has told Tory activists to brace for a tough night. Key battles will be over  councils in “no overall control”. More than half the seats up for grabswere meant to be elected in  but delayed due to Covid. Likewise, seats include  by-elections that were delayed by the pandemic. WHERE  Almost everywhere in England.SCOTTISH PARLIAMENT: All  seats are being chosen and Nicola Sturgeon will be hoping to win an overall majority - which she’s just short of now. Polls leave little doubt the SNP will be the largest party but Opinium say an overall majority is too close to call. If the nationalists up their seat tally from  to , they will push for a new independence referendum - seven years after last losing their fight. However, they’re also facing a fight with Alex Salmondaposs Alba party which wants a “super-majority” for independence. Labour, with new leader Anas Sarwar, is trailing in third place on  seats but isnapost expecting to leapfrog the Tories after hitting rock bottom last year - instead the party wants a  to rebuild. WHERE  Everywhere in Scotland.WELSH PARLIAMENT: All  seats are up for grabs and polls suggest Labour - while the biggest party - has an uphill struggle to win an overall majority. First Minister Mark Drakeford has ruled out an independence referendum as the price of any pact, but could need a deal with Plaid Cymru or the Lib Demshe’s to form a minority government. This is one of UKIP’s last outposts, where ex-Tory Neil Hamilton clings on for Nigel Farage’s old party even after he abandoned it. WHERE  Everywhere in Wales. ENGLISH MAYORS: Londonaposs mayoral election is the biggest but Labour’s Sadiq Khan is on course for an easy victory. The biggest battles are over Tory-held Tees Valley and West Midlands. Labour wants a Red Wall upset to seize West Midlands but hopes appear slim in Tees Valley. Voters are also electing two other metro mayors in Labour-held Greater Manchester and Liverpool City Region. There are three combined authority mayoral elections - Tory-held West of England and Cambridgeshire  Peterborough, along with new mayoralty West Yorkshire., where Labour MP an ex-soap star Tracy Brabin wants a win. And finally five single-authority mayors - all currently held by Labour - are up for election in Bristol, Liverpool, Salford, Doncaster and North Tyneside. WHERE  Everywhere in the regions of Greater London, Greater Manchester, West Midlands, Tees Valley, Liverpool City Region, West Yorkshire, and Cambridgeshire  Peterborough. Plus Bristol, North Tyneside and Doncaster.HARTLEPOOL BY-ELECTION: The blockbuster Westminster ballot. Eyebrow-raising polls are tipping the Tories want to wipe out Labour’s , majority in the Brexit-backing northern seat - which has been red since its creation in  - with as much as a -point lead. If Labour candidate, the former MP Dr Paul Williams, fails Boris Johnson will hail it as a coup. Pollsters though point out the vote was split by the Brexit Party in , so the seat might otherwise have fallen to the Tories back then. WHERE  Only the Hartlepool Westminster constituency. LONDON ASSEMBLY: All  seats are up for election and Labour will be straining for an overall majority - the party’s currently one seat short on . Polling has suggested Labour is at least  points ahead of the Tories but the ‘list’ system introduces unknowns and allows voters to give a leg up to smaller parties. The Greens and ‘ Brexit Alliance’ each have two seats on the Assembly. WHERE  Everywhere in Greater London. POLICE COMMISSIONERS: The oft-forgotten jobs are up for election for the third time since they were created in . When they first emerged  were Independents but that shrank to just three in . Labour won  of the posts last time while the Tories won . But given their role as one single person overseeing police - and the fact many are being declared last - these jobs will end up as a sideshow to the main political news of election weekend. WHERE  Everywhere in England and Wales except Greater London and Greater Manchester, where the mayor is also the commissioner. Thursday  May: From pm Put the kettle on and keep it near for  hours. Polls close across Great Britain and counting starts for the Hartlepool by-election, Doncaster mayor and  of  English councils. Unlike in normal years, most results will only start being counted on Friday morning - and in some cases much later. This is because there are more elections than usualand counting is much slower .Friday  May: From amResults start trickling in from the  overnight councils in England.They include Derby which has swung from Labour to Tory-run no overall controlin recent years. And Southend has been run by a Labour, Lib Dem and Green ‘rainbow coalition’ since the Tory leader was voted out in . Likewise the Tories only need a few gains to take back Colchester from a Labour-Lib Dem coalition.Harlow is solidly Labour-controlled but has backed Conservatives in the past - could it slip into NOC on a good night for Tories  Labour meanwhile will be eyeing Thurrock , run by Tories but which has swung back and forth into NOC over the years. And the Tories seized Redditch from Labour in , so on a good night Keir Starmer’s party would want to make in-roads there. Labour strongholds Gateshead , Newcastle, Knowsley, Sunderland, Oldham, South Tyneside and Rochdale all declare early. Friday  May: From am The Hartlepool by-election result is due around am. If the Tories overturn Labour’s , majority and claim the Westminster seat for the first time in its history, it will likely lead the day’s news and be a big political headache for Keir Starmer. We should get our first mayor result in the Doncaster mayoral election, currently held by Labour. And we could get some of the most interesting of the overnight council results, including Dudley where Labour and the Tories are almost neck-and-neck. Also declaring at sunrise are Stockport , a Labour-Lib Dem split in NOC, and Nuneaton  Bedworth which could go red, blue or NOC. On a good night the Tories will want to seize control of Northumberland where they rule in a minority. Friday  May: From amIf you’ve stayed up overnight, go to bed. No more results are likely during the morning. But from am, counting begins for an avalanche of races - all  seats for the Welsh Parliament, half the London Assembly,  of the  constituencies for the Scottish Parliament, and  councils in England. Counting also starts for three of the  elections for police and crime commissioners, and the Liverpool mayor. Friday  May: From Noon Lunchtime council results start rolling in, including Burnley where Labour only needs one more seat to take control. Tories only need small gains to take control of Bolton but it won’t be an easy fight. Red fortress Manchester declares in the early afternoon as do less strongly Labour-held Rossendale and Tory Devon .Castle Point is a straight fight between Tories and the powerful Canvey Island independents who want their own council. Meanwhile we’ll get the mayor of Liverpool, a Labour stronghold but home to a furious row over the party’s selection of their candidate.Many of the most important Scottish Parliament results will roll in at some point on Friday afternoon.They include Dumbarton where Labour’s deputy leader Jackie Baillie clung on by whisker against the SNP in . Labour are likewise fighting hard to defend Edinburgh Southern and East Lothian against an SNP challenge. Despite speculation of a three-way fight, they believe either the SNP or Tories will take Edinburgh Central .Eastwood was a three-way fight in , won by the Scottish Tories. The big name race is in Glasgow Southside where new leader Anas Sarwar is challenging First Minister Nicola Sturgeon. He’ll lose, but get in on the regional list system instead and Labour are hoping to dent the SNP majority.Friday  May: From pmWe’re due the first results from Wales, including the Parliament’s most marginal seat Llanelli where Plaid Cymru are challenging Labour. Welsh Labour will also be fighting off the Tories in Wrexham , a key brick in a so-called red wall.Elsewhere, we’ll start getting the first seven results for the London Assembly and the first police commissioners in Avon and Somerset and Staffordshire. And an avalanche of English council results begins as the afternoon wears on. Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire turned blue recently and a strong Labour performance should at least kick them into NOC. Ex-minister Edwina Currie - yes her! - is standing against Labour ex-MP Ruth George to become a Derbyshire councillor. Seizing back Trafford from the Tories was Labour’s big victory in  so the party must hold on now to avoid a reverse humiliation.Cornwall is run by a Lib Dem-Independent coalition but the Tories have the most seats and will be hoping to gain. Ex-UKIP territory Basildon will be a hard Labour-Tory fight but could stay in NOC. On a bad night for Labour the party could lose Bury , Sheffield or West Lancashire to NOC, while Tories could gain Maidstone in a tussle with Lib Dems. Tories have no seats in Sheffield or Sandwell - will they up their count to one Friday  May: From pm The Tees Valley metro mayor result is due, with Tory Ben Houchen tipped to hang on against his Labour challenger in the former ‘red wall’. And in Wales we’ll get the Labour marginals of Caerphilly and Vale of Clwyd where Plaid and Tories respectively are putting up a fight. Lib Dems are also defending their only seat in Brecon and Radnorshire - and will Rhondda stay Plaid in the Valleys Over in England, about  councils are due to declare in the space of just  minutes.The biggest races include Norfolk , Cambridgeshire , Essex, counties up for all-out election that are Tory-run but could give Labour inroads.Cambridge also has all its seats up for election in a battle between Labour and the Lib Dems. On good nights for the main parties, Labour could win Wirral and Crawley or the Tories could win Pendle and Elmbridge from NOC. Labour’s first county, Durham , should stay red - as should Doncaster but the Tories might look for small in-roads asall its seats are up. Labour only need to lose a few seats in Plymouth to lose to NOC but the Tories wouldn’t be able to form a majority. Likewise Tory-run Walsall could fall to NOC on a bad night for Boris Johnson.Solihull is unusual - it’s Tory-run but with a Green opposition and the Conservatives will lose controlthey’re docked one seat.Friday  May: From pmMore than a dozen final results flood in for the Welsh Parliament, making clear whether Labour will need to form a coalition.Key declarations include Tory target Vale of Glamorgan and First Minister Mark Drakeford’s seat Cardf West. Likewise by the end of the night we’ll have results for  of the  Scottish Parliament seats, giving some early indication of whether Nicola Sturgeon’s on course for an outright majority.About a dozen more English council results should come in during the evening including Hull, where Labour want to keep Lib Dems at bay.Mole Valley has slim Lib Dem control with a Tory and Independent challenge while Worcester could go Tory or Labour.No results are expected overnight on Friday unless a particular council chooses to push things late into the night.Saturday  May: From amNormally elections would be over by Saturday - but counting will resume in earnest this year. But go out for brunch or something - the results shouldn’t roll in until noon or so. There will be all remaining constituency seats and all regional seats in Scotland,  councils in England, the rest of the London Assembly and at least  police commissioners. Counts will also begin in the mayoral elections for London, Bristol, Greater Manchester, Liverpool City Region, North Tyneside, Salford, the West of England and the West Midlands.Saturday  May: From Noon The first results from the  English councils counting on Saturday, including Lancashire which the Tories took from NOC in . Aside from this there may be few surprises in England until later in the afternoon. Oxford and North Tyneside are both Labour while Shropshire, Worcester, Broxbourne and Hertfordshire are all Tory . Eastleigh is solidly Lib Dem. We could get the Liverpool City mayor and the North Tyneside mayor , both likely Labour, and the West of England mayor , which the Tories won by a slim margin in . In Scotland we should get results in Aberdeenshire West, which the Tories took from the SNP by a slim margin in , and key target seat Perthshire South which the Tories want to take from the SNP this time. Saturday  May: From pm The key result for the West Midlands mayor - which Labour ex-minister Liam Byrne wants to seize from Tory incumbent Andy Street. If he can pull it off it’d be a key symbolic victory for Keir Starmer in territory where the Tories gained much ground under Corbyn.We should get results from mid-afternoon for the rest of the London Assembly constituencies, but the mayor will only be later in the evening.We should however get confirmation ‘king of the north’ Andy Burnham has been re-elected as Greater Manchester mayor . And results for  police and crime commissioners are likely. The results for the Salford mayor are also due. About  more English council results should flood in mid to late afternoon including Hartlepool, where the Tories are part of a complex coalition and turnout should be high due to the by-election. Labour need just three seats to take control of Kirklees but the Tories have previously gained ground in the area. Meanwhile the Lib Dems would only need a few seats to seize Gosport from the Conservatives.Milton Keynes is a three-way fight between Labour and the Lib Dems, currently in coalition under NOC, and the Tories. The Lib Dems and Tories will both be vying to retake NOC Portsmouth while the Lib Dems and Labour will want to regain seats they lost in Tory Wiltshire. Stroud is interesting - NOC with a rainbow coalition of Labour, Greens and Lib Dems but Tories are the largest party. And Rotherham doesn’t have a single Tory, will it stay that way

local-elections--live-polls- serviceresponsiveembeddedArticleUrl" data-chronos-domain"https:livecentreps-cdn-prod.tm-awx " data-inview"true"Voting in todayaposs crucial aposSuper Thursdayapos elections is entering its crucial final few hours Keir Starmer and Boris Johnson were among those casting their ballots early on Thursday. They have been followed by Mayor of London Sadiq Khan and his Tory rival Shaun Bailey.Polls close at pm in what is Starmeraposs first major test as Labour leader, with supporters eager to see progress is being made after the disastrous defeat in the  General Election under his predecessor Jeremy Corbyn.Labour Party hope to make gains on councils, retain power in the Welsh Senedd and hold on to the stronghold of Hartlepool in a crunch parliamentary by-election.There is a lot at stake in Scotland, where the SNP are battling to achieve a majority in the Scottish Parliament - something Nicola Sturgeon believes will push Boris Johnson into agreeing to a second independence referendum.Meanwhile the Tories are hoping to hold on to metro mayoralties in the West Midlands and Teesside, and make further inroads in the so-called aposRed Wallapos areas in the Midlands and North.Out on the campaign trail, Starmer said: “We’ve got to rebuild into the next general election – that is the task at hand.”For the latest on the local elections, follow our updates below :Matthew DreschWhat time do polling stations close today Polling stations have opened, and it#xs time to cast your vote in the local elections .Around  million people are eligible to vote today, Thursday May , in England, Scotland and Wales.Polling stations opened at am this morning, but there is plenty of time left to vote.The polling stations will close at pm, after which you won#xt be able to vote #x but there is a small exception.Click here to read the full story. :Jeremy CulleyKhan says London turnout lowSadiq Khan says turnout across the capital has reportedly been low today in a bid to shore up his support.The Labour London Mayor is expected to be re-elected fairly comfortably, but is clearly not getting complacent and doesnapost want Labour supporters to think itaposs a done deal. He tweeted: LONDON: reports show that voter turnout is low across our city.If you love London  what we stand for, please come out and vote for it.We had a Tory mayor just five years ago -you donapost vote, they could win again.Already voted  Please RT and ask friends to #xAVoteLabour. :Dave BurkeHari gets into the spirit as race for London Mayor heats upMore dogs at polling stations content.This is Hari, pictured in Bexley, South London, today.Owner Steven Reilly-Hii said: We passed the polling station on the way to the park, I#xd already done a postal vote, but thought I#xd get into the spirit of things with a photo on twitter as we went by. Hari was more concerned with getting to the park, but he did take an interest in the nearby bin, and avoided a fox poo near to the polling station, so not surethere#xs any clues as to his mayor of London vote within that. :Dan BloomWhat results will we actually get overnight Very few. Only  or so councils are counting overnight, with most of them - along with the Scottish and Welsh Parliaments - only getting going on Friday or Saturday.They include Derby which has swung from Labour to Tory-run no overall controlin recent years.And Southend has been run by a Labour, Lib Dem and Green #xrainbow coalition#x since the Tory leader was voted out in .But the biggest overnight result headline-wise will be the Hartlepool by-election. Polls have tipped the Tories to win the Westminster seat, which has been Labour since its creation in .:Dave BurkeVoters brave the weather to take part in the democratic processThe stakes are high on Super Thursday as voters in England, Scotland and Wales go to the polls.It is the first time people have had the chance to vote en masse since the start of the pandemic, with the results set to provide an indication how Labouraposs recovery is going under Keir Starmer.And in Scotland the results of the Parliamentary election could determine whether thereaposs another move toward indepence, with Nicola Sturgeon expected to force the issue with Whitehallher SNP does well. :Dave BurkeWhat war with France fishing dispute is about - and why its happened on election dayA tense stand off is taking place in waters around Jersey after two Royal Navy gunships were ordered to patrol a potential blockade by furious French fishermen.Boris Johnson sent two offshore patrol vessels to monitor the situation at the Channel Island on Wednesday night as a dispute erupted over post-Brexit fishing rights.On Thursday morning, dozens of French fishing boats gathered outside St Helier in protest at changes to fishing rules, prompting fears they might attempt to blockade the harbour.The timing of the row is pretty extraordinary as voters head to the polls for the first elections since .Dubbed Super Thursday, elections are being held for councillors, mayors and police and crime commissioners, as well as parliamentary elections in Wales and Scotland.The escalation in tensions over fishing in Jerseyaposs waters is a coincidence - and the Prime Minister is required to act in support of the Crown Dependency.Click here for the full story :Dave BurkeNuns have their say as Scotland goes to the pollsItaposs a big day north of the border, with a lot at stake in Scotlandaposs Parliamentary elections.These pictures show a group of five sisters from Carmelite Monastery in Dysart cast their vote at Dysart Community Hall, West Port, Dysart.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is expected to lock horns with Downing Street over independenceher SNP party is successful.:Dave BurkeTory MP tweets wrong flag from  years ago to celebrate election dayA Tory MPaposs attempt to celebrate election day by waving a flag backfired when she used a -year-old version that doesnapost include Northern Ireland.Andrea Jenkyns shared the emblem on Twitter just after .am as polls prepared to open across England, Wales and Scotland.But instead of the current Union flag, she shared the flag of Great Britain - without Northern Ireland - that was used from the early s until the beginning of .The version is missing the diagonal cross of St Patrick of Ireland.Click here for the full story :Dave BurkeCouncil confirms church warder did oversleep ahead of polling station openingEarlier on today The Mirror reported that a baffled voter had to cast his vote in the back of a car because a church warder aposoversleptapos.Toby Porter said he cast his vote in Oxford at .am, and the normal polling station was up and running by .am.He said around a dozen people voted in the car before the centre at the Oxford Centre for Mission Studies was opened.We found it funny. Everyone was enjoying the novelty, he told the PA news agency.Now a spokesman for Oxford city council has explained what happened.He said: #xCThe keyholder overslept and for a short time at am electors were voting using the POs#xcars. This is standard procedure when a station building isn#xt open on time and part of the training we give them. The key is that ballot papers are ready to be issued at am, wherever that may be. The building was open within  minutes.#xD A spokesman for Oxford city council said: #xCThe keyholder overslept and for a short time at am electors were voting using the POs#xcars. This is standard procedure when a station building isn#xt open on time and part of the training we give them. The key is that ballot papers are ready to be issued at am, wherever that may be. The building was open within  minutes.#xD :Dave BurkeSome of our favourite dogs at polling stations so farPolitics often brings out the worst in people, so itaposs heartening that amid all the bickering one election day tradition is bringing people together.For the last few years it has been obligatory for dog owners to snap their pets outside polling stations, and today is no dferent.Here is a selection of our favourites.First time voting as a dog owner so obligatory #dogsatpollingstations pic. pic cavTarIJznmdash Daniel Dylan WrayMay ,  Fantastic turnout in Dulwich Village! #dogsatpollingstations #superthursday #londonmayor pic ytpUdjmdash Anna SkipwithMay ,  Taking your pooch to the polls  You know the drill, send us your pics! #DogsAtPollingStationsHere’s Max to show you how it’s done: pic jXJvqIvSmdash Dogs TrustMay ,  Tobin can#t vote, since he#s American. But he still believes in the importance of the democratic process #dogsatpollingstations pic qFYJYNqfMmdash Martin OrchardMay ,  :Dave BurkeVoters battle through snow to get to polling stations on crucial day in ScotlandSpare a thought for the people of Farr, close to Inverness, today.While it might be a bit chilly across most of the country, people there have to battle through more than most.Pictures show the village cloaked in snow on election day. Scottish Parliamentary elections could be crucial today, with parties urging as many people as possible to have their say.However because Covid will slow down counting, it could be  hours before people find out the result.:Dave BurkeNicola Sturgeon visits polling station in crucial election in ScotlandFirst Minister Nicola Sturgeon has met voters at a Glasgow polling station on the morning of what her party has dubbed one of Scotlandaposs most important elections.The SNP leader visited Annette Street Primary School in Govanhill - part of her Glasgow Southside constituency - along with Roza Salih, who is the lead SNP candidate on the Glasgow regional list.At the polling station, Ms Sturgeon and Ms Salih met three Syrian Scots who have lived in Scotland for eight years - -year-old Adnan Abdulbaki, and Iqbal Abdulbaki and Abdulruhman Abdulbaki, both  - as they prepared to cast their vote.Ms Sturgeon said it is great weaposve got everybody who lives here able to vote, saying it is an exciting and special thing to do, to which they agreed. :Dave BurkeSadiq Khan brings dog to polling station as he looks to continue as London mayorBringing dogs to polling stations is a long established tradition, and Sadiq Khan - who is seeking re-election as mayor of London - has joined in.The Labour candidate, who has led the city since , brought pet Luna with him as his we Saadiya cast her vote.Mr Khan has already voted by post. :Dave BurkePM issues rallying cry to votersPrime Minister Boris Johnson shared a video on Twitter encouraging people to go out and vote.It’s a very big day at the polls today. I hope everybody will go out and vote.Vote for the @Conservatives today. pic blembNNBmdash Boris JohnsonMay ,  :Dave BurkeScottish Labour leader casts votes as he calls on public to back partyThe leaders of Scotlandaposs political parties are heading to the polls to cast their own votes in the Scottish Parliament election.Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar voted at his local polling station at Pollokshields Burgh Hall in Glasgow on Thursday morning.Mr Sarwar is standing against First Minister Nicola Sturgeon in the Glasgow Southside constituency, which includes Pollokshields.Flanked by his we and four-year-old son, Mr Sarwar was in a buoyant mood, chatting with voters and answering questions from journalists.He said he used both votes for Scottish Labour and urged other voters to do the same. :Dave BurkeKeir Starmer casts his vote on crucial day for his leadershipLabour leader Keir Starmer has cast his vote today in a crucial day for his leadership.He and we Victoria were pictured outside the Greenwood Centre polling station in North London.He has called on voters to deliver a blow to Boris Johnson as he attempts to claw back from Labouraposs disastrous  General Election campaign. :Dave BurkeIts one rule for them, another for the rest of us says StarmerLabouraposs Keir Starmer has called on voters to punish the Tories for cronyism as they go to the polls today.He tweeted: From bending tax rules for those who have Boris Johnsonaposs phone number and handing out contracts to their mates to wasting your money on contracts that don#xt deliver. It#xs one rule for them, another for the rest of us. Thereaposs a clear choice at todayaposs elections.starmer tweet:Dave BurkeHandy tool tells you where your nearest polling station isNot sure where you should be casting your vote  This handy tool will help.Just type in your postcode and find out where your nearest polling station is.See your nearest polling station for the local elections or visit InYourArea:Dave BurkeLabour leaders final message to voters ahead of crunch electionLabour leader Keir Starmer has said it would take time to rebuild his party after the worst general election result since  under Jeremy Corbyn, adding: I never thought we would climb the mountain we have to climb in just one year.In his final message to voters he said: This is a changed Labour Party. Under new leadership, we are putting working people and their communities first.Your priorities will always be Labouraposs priorities, with Labour councils, councillors and mayors utterly focused on delivering the secure jobs, safer streets and health services we all want to see.They are the first step of Labouraposs plan to rebuild Britain, based on security and opportunities across the country. :Dave BurkePublic cast votes in car after church warder oversleptA reminder that in election times, everything doesnapost run smoothly all the time.Voter Toby Porter posted a picture of ballot box in the back of the car, after the church where polling was due to happen was locked.He wrote: The church warden has overslept apparently so just cast my vote in a car.The church warden has overslept apparently so just cast my vote in a car. #LocalElections pic AstsGWlYmdash Toby PorterMay ,  :Dave BurkeKey battles to watch - and where Labour must winThe Mirror has compiled a handy round-up of the key reas to keep an eye on as the Super Thursday results come in.The most high-profile race is the Hartlepool by-election., but council results in Durham, Bury and Rotherham will be telling as Keir Starmer faces his first test at the polls.Labour will be hoping for a good result in Tory-controlled Basildon, while the West Midlands metro mayoral race is a key test for Keir Starmeraposs leadership of Labour.Click here for the full run-down :Dave BurkePre-election poll gives Tories vaccine bounce lead over LabourPre-election polling suggests the Tories are enjoying a aposvaccine bounceapos - giving them a signicant lead over the opposition.Research by YouGov for The Times found Boris Johnson and co had a -point lead over Labour - just one point down from a week ago.Nearly ninety per cent thought the vaccine programme had been handled well, with half of them crediting the Prime Minister.More than half of the public thought the governmentaposs response to the pandemic had been bad, but only one in five thought Labour would have done better, according to The Times.The poll, carried out on Tuesday and Wednesday, put the Tories nationally on  per cent - ahead of Labour on  per cent.:Dave BurkeVoters go to the polls in crucial Hartlepool by-electionVoters are having their say in the cruical Hartlepool by-election today, with polling stations beginning to fill up.The by-election will indicate what progress -any - Labour has made in regaining votes in its former northern heartlands.Hartlepool was held by Labour with a majority of , in  even as other bricks in the so-called red wall crumbled - in part due to the Brexit Party splitting the Tory vote.Defeat would be a blow to Sir Keir Starmer and provide a rare by-election gain for a governing party.Boris Johnson sought to manage expectations ahead of the elections, playing down his chances of taking Hartlepool - despite one recent poll putting the Tories  points clear and bookmakers making Conservative candidate Jill Mortimer clear favourite to win the seat.:Dave BurkeBoris Johnson arrives to cast his voteThe Prime Minister has arrived to cast his vote in Westminster this morning.He faces a crucial day at the polls - with todayaposs election the first natiowide poll since the start of pandemic.Boris Johnson was accompanied by partner Carrie Symonds as he arrived at a Westminster polling station. :Dave BurkeSome results probably wont be known until Monday with slower counting than normalMillions of Brits are voting today for  councils,  police commissioners,  mayors, two national parliaments, the London Assembly and the Hartlepool by-election.The #xSuper Thursday#x elections are the first ballot box test of Boris Johnson and Keir Starmer since the pandemic - with all eyes on the by-election which polls are tipping the Tories to take.This weekaposs elections will also decide whether Labour have to rule in coalition in Wales, and whether Nicola Sturgeon gets the SNP majority she craves - allowing her a fresh push for Scottish independence.But it could be some time until we find out whataposs happened.Results will start appearing in the early hours of Friday, but counting is slower than usual due to Covid restrictions and the number of dferent elections - up to four or five in some areas.It#xs thought the full picture may not be known until late in the weekend or Monday.Click here for a full run-down of when to expect results in your areas. :Dave BurkeWhat youll need to bring in order to voteIn order to vote in the local elections, you need to register to vote.The deadline for  has passed, but you can still register to vote in upcoming elections.You also need to check that you#xre eligible to vote, which you can doyou#xre: years old in England and Northern Ireland years old in Scottish Parliament and local elections  years old in Welsh Parliament elections You must also be registered at an address in the area you want to vote in, and not be legally excluded from voting.You can voteyou#xre a British citizen, as well as an EU or qualying Commonwealth citizen.You can also voteyou#xre a citizen of another country who is living in Scotland or Wales who has permission to stay in the UK, or does not need permission.If you#xre voting at a polling station, there are a few things you need to remember.Firstly, you don#xt need to bring your polling card, but it may help to speed up the processyou do.If you live in England, Scotland or Wales you don#xt need to bring your ID.Because of the coronavirus pandemic, there are a few changes you do need to be aware of.In order to vote safely, you need to wear a face covering, unless exempt.You are also encouraged to bring your own pen or pencil #x but there will be clean ones availableyou forget.You#xll also be encouraged to use hand sanitiser when you arrive, and when you leave. :Dave BurkeKeir Starmer says today is but a step in the road toward ing to powerKeir Starmer has described Thursday#xs elections as #xCbut a step in the road#xD towards Labour #xsto power, as polls #xADsuggest the party faces key defeats.The Labour leader on Wednesday toured the country campaigning for #xCevery last vote#xD in the swathe of #xCSuper Thursday#xD council, mayoral and national contests.As voters go to the polls today, he sets out his five-point plan to put Labour firmly on the path back to power, promising #xCa brighter, better future for you, your family and your community#xD.Writing in the Mirror, he says: #xCI#xm driven by a burning desire to make this country the best place to grow up in and the best place to grow old in, whoever you are and wherever you live.#xDBut he insisted that rebuilding the party after its worst general election defeat in more than  years under Jeremy Corbyn would take time.Out on the campaign trail, he said: #xCWe#xve got to rebuild into the next general election #x that is the task at hand.#xDPolls suggest Labour could be hammered in the Hartlepool #xADby-election as the post-Brexit sht continues and the Tories benefit from a #xCvaccine bounce#xD.Click here for the full story More OnNicola SturgeonBoris JohnsonScottish GovernmentLabour PartyReferendumPolitics

title: local elections 2021 what time
story: NewsLocal elections : What time do polling stations close today Millions of people will take to the polling stations today for the local elections . You will have plenty of time to cast your vote, but make sure you do it before polling stations closemirrorShareCommentsByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsIts local election day " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Polling stations have opened, and it’s time to cast your vote in the local elections .Around  million people are eligible to vote today, Thursday May , in England, Scotland and Wales. Citizens will be able to vote in ious elections depending on where they are in the country. Voters will be electing  English local councils,  Members of the Scottish Parliament,  Members of the Welsh Senedd,  Police and Crime Commissioners,  London Assembly seats and  directly-elected mayors. Many people will be taking to the polling stations for the first time – or perhaps just need a little reminder of how to vote today. Here is everything you need to know, including when polling stations close. When do polling stations close  Polling stations opened at am this morning, but there is plenty of time left to vote. The polling stations will close at pm, after which you won’t be able to vote – but there is a small exception. Polling stations tend to get really busy, especially towards the end of the day. If the polling station is very busy around this time, and a queue has formed, you may be able to vote still. However, this is only the caseyou joined the queue before pm.  Most people would have already received a polling card in the post. Details about where you can go to vote will be printed on the card, usually along with a map. You have to go to the designated polling station you have been allocated. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  The polling station will usually be a short distance from your home, in public building such as a school or leisure centre.If you have lost your card, you can put your postcode in to find out where your polling place is on the Electoral Commission website. How to vote

title: tory mp tweets wrongflag 400
story: NewsTory MP tweets wrong flag from  years ago to celebrate election dayAndrea Jenkyns bid at patriotism backfired as she hastily removed the flag - which stopped being used in  because it doesnt incorporate Northern IrelandmirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsAndrea Jenkyns nod to patriotism went a bit wrong" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA Tory MPaposs attempt to celebrate election day by waving a flag backfired when she used a -year-old version that doesnapost include Northern Ireland.Andrea Jenkyns shared the emblem on Twitter just after .am as polls prepared to open across England, Wales and Scotland.But instead of the current Union flag, she shared the flag of Great Britain - without Northern Ireland - that was used from the early s until the beginning of . The version is missing the diagonal cross of St Patrick of Ireland.It is perhaps fitting, as tensions rise in Northern Ireland over trade issues in the Brexit deal - and as some accuse the Tory government of abandoning the region.But Brexiteer Ms Jenkyns insisted she wasnapost trying to make a political point.  Ms Jenkyns told the Mirror: It was an honest mistake, been up since the crack of dawn for elections, quickly tweeted, and later saw my mistake so deleted. Note to self, check and double check!! Given the amount of flag-waving Tory politicians have done recently - including putting them prominently in the background of TV interviews - Ms Jenkyns was roundly teased online. Twitter user Otto English said: Took Andrea Jenkyns MP a whole hour to remember what her own countryaposs flag looks like. They wrap themselves in it but they donapost know what it even is. Millions of Brits are voting on May  for  councils,  police commissioners,  mayors, two national parliaments, the London Assembly and the Hartlepool by-election. The ‘Super Thursday’ elections are far bigger than normal - because they include thousands of contests which were postponed from May  due to Covid.The bumper results will be the first ballot box test of Boris Johnson and Keir Starmer since the pandemic.

title: voice mirror elections opportunity vote
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Elections an opportunity to vote for better future under LabourLabour mayors and councillors are delivering jobs, protecting local services and investing in their communities in contrast to the waste, cronyism and incomp­etence of Boris Johnson’s governmentmirrorShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAY NewsopinionYou have an opportunity to vote for a better future under Labour " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThursdayaposs elections could prove a pivotal moment in this country’s history. At stake is the future of the UK and the prosperity of millions of people. Across the land Labour has shown it is best placed to meet the challenges of our time. Andy Burnham has proved to be a proud and forceful champion of Greater Manchester. In the West Midlands, only Labour’s Liam Byrne has the vision required to bring jobs and investment to the region. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section London mayor Sadiq Khan has delivered on his promises to build more homes and create a greener capital, while in Wales First Minister Mark Drakeford deserves praise for his deft handling of the Covid crisis. It is Labour mayors and councillors who are delivering jobs, protecting local services and investing in their communities. This stands in contrast to the waste, cronyism and incomp­etence of Boris Johnson’s government. At the polling booth today you do not just have a chance to hold the Tories to account. You have an opportunity to vote for a better future under Labour. BBC pay a joke Graham Norton once said it was “pathetic” that the BBC had to reveal how much it paid its star presenters. Now we have an idea why he holds this view.  Accounts show he is getting more than £million a year to make his chat show. Perhaps Norton believes he’s value for money. More than three million pensioners aged over  may take a dferent view. They now have to pay for their TV licence as the BBC says it cannot afford it. The BBC needs to ask itself what is better value for money. Looking after its loyal audience or lavishing already well-rewarded stars with ever more lucrative contracts  Tots of fun

title: ashes tattoos mcdonalds visits 9
story: AdvertorialFrom ashes tattoos to McDonalds visits:  unexpected things seen at British funeralsThese are some of the genuine things British people have asked for at their own funerals, according to Co-op Funeralcare - the UKs No funeral services providermirrorShareByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialHow us Brits think about and plan for our funerals is changing.Just one in ten people now want a traditional religious send-off, while two fths see funerals becoming more informal in the future, according to a report* from Co-op Funeralcare.Julia Samuel, author of Grief Works, says making funeral choices in advance is a great idea. She explains: As scary as it may seem to talk about death and our end of le wishes, it’s infinitely preferable to leaving our loved ones wonderingthey made the right decisions.Below, weaposve listed  fascinating things British people have asked for at their own funerals in recent years.. To arrive in a motorcycle hearse Some  per cent of Co-op’s funeral directors have been asked to source a unique hearse for a funeral.. To be buried with a Chinese takeaway . For a giant packet of Werther’s Original made from flowers . For part of the funeral to take place at a McDonaldaposs Drive-Thru Whilst three quarters of Co-op’s employees have had requests for funerals to take place outside of traditional religious settings, two fths of people say they didn’t know it was even possible to have a funeral at another location.. For their ashes to be turned into a tattoo . For their coffin to arrive on an Only Fools and Horses Hearse . For part of their funeral to take place next to the th hole on a golf course

title: bald men up two half
story: NewsBald men up to two-and-a-half times more likely to suffer severe Covid symptomsScientists say the male sex hormones called androgens - which cause hair loss - make them more susceptible to having the most severe symptoms of coronavirusmirrorShareCommentsByKelly-Ann MillsReporterMark Waghorn:,  MAY NewsBald men affected badly by covid " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBald men are up to two-and-a-half times more likely to suffer severe Covid symptoms, according to the latest research. Scientists say the male sex hormones called androgens - that cause hair loss - make them more susceptible. It could explain the gender gap in deaths, with men twice as likely to succumb to the disease and the discovery could revolutionise treatment of patients and slash mortality rates.Men carrying mutations sensitive to androgens - which include testosterone - were found to be prone to worse coronavirus symptoms, researchers say.Scientists have also found similar results in women who are losing their hair due to androgens. A US team noticed  per cent of hospitalised patients had androgenetic alopecia - commonly known as male pattern baldness. This was dramatically disproportionate to the  to  percent in a similar age-matched population. The condition is caused by iants in a gene called AR, which regulates a protein known as TMPRSS - that is implicated in coronavirus. A study of  men hospitalised with the infection showed those with low CAG levels were at less risk of being admitted to the intensive care unit. Researchers say this could be a game-changer in combatting the pandemic. Lead author Dr Andy Goren, chief medical officer at Applied Biology, Inc, Irvine, Calornia, said: Our data show longer AR CAG scores are associated with more severe COVID- disease. The identication of a biomarker connected with the androgen receptor is another piece of evidence highlighting the important role of androgens in COVID- disease severity. The researchers also identied a promising therapy using a novel drug that blocks the androgen receptor. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.

title: brits surprised how well coronavirus
story: NewsBrits surprised by how well Coronavirus vaccine rollout has gone, poll suggestsA survey of , adults in England wascommissioned by private Covid testing company Medicspot and found  per cent say the restrictions are not strict enough and  per cent think they are too strictmirrorShareCommentsByAdrian Hearn:,  MAY NewsBrits are looking forward to restrictions easing " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeMore than half of adults in England think the government is doing a good job of managing the pandemic - but itaposs not a case of aposjab doneapos yet, according to a poll commissioned by a private Covid testing company. The survey of , adults in England reports to have found  per cent think the vaccination rollout has been a success for the nation. And of those who think it is a triumph,  per cent admit they have been surprised with just how well it has gone. Overall,  per cent of those polled reportedly agreed the government has done a good job managing the pandemic this year. With the roadmap, which should move onto the next stage on May , the survey by private Covid testing company Medicspot found  per cent think the restrictions are about right, with  per cent saying it is not strict enough. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section While  per cent think itaposs too strict. The public is almost twice as likely to want the government to continue down its current path, with  per cent against lting restrictions early compared to  per cent who do want this to happen. However, while pubs are now partly open,  per cent have been put off going to one because they didnapost want to sit outside. And two thirds hate having to organise a trip to the pub rather than being able to go for a spur of the moment drink. Almost four in also think it is unfair they can order food inside a takeaway but have to be served outside in a pub. The Government is set to announce its latest updates on holidaying abroad shortly, with numerous European nations expected to be added to the aposgreen listapos of places to visit.This will be welcomed by the public, after  per cent said Boris Johnson and his team need to provide more clarity on when theyaposll be allowed to holiday abroad.More than a quarterof respondents said they are hoping to go abroad this year - and of those,  per cent plan to make it a post-Covid blowout holiday. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here. A spokesperson for Medicspot, which provides day  and  Covid test packages, said: The government has had its fair share of criticism with its response to the pandemic over the past  months, but the public appears to be backing its actions this year.A lot of this is down to the rollout of the vaccine, which has been a fantastic success. The next step is for holidays abroad and itaposs clear many people are crossing their fingers in the hope they get to enjoy a bit of European sun this summer. When it comes to leaving the country,  per cent think you should have to present both a negative Covid test result and proof you have been vaccinated.  A fth think proof youaposre vaccinated is good enough to jump on-board an aircraft, while  per cent think you should only need a negative Covid test result to go abroad. The survey, carried out via OnePoll, found  per cent are more relaxed about the threat posed by Covid now infections are lower. And  per cent think vaccinated people should be able to meet and socialise inside other vaccinated peopleaposs homes. Half said they thought the Covid vaccine should be compulsory, while a thirdwere against this.

title: extra bank holiday september suggested
story: NewsExtra Bank Holiday in September suggested to give tourism and hospitality a boostTravel and hospitality bosses are urging the Government to add a new Bank Holiday after Monday proved a washout for many who had hoped to recoup losses after a dismal wintermirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  MAY NewsThe May Day Bank Holiday was not the top earner the industry hoped for " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAn extra Bank Holiday in September could be on the cards to recoup lossestravel and hospitality bosses get their way. Industry chiefs are urging Downing Street to take action after the much-anticipated May Day break - the first holiday since Covid restrictions eased - was hit by heavy rain.For many businesses, it was the second Bank Holiday they had been able to welcome customers in over a year but the weather put many people off venturing out. Kate Nicholls, chief executive of UK Hospitality, wrote on Twitter : Hospitality and tourism has missed out on almost all bank holidays last year and the start of this.An extra bank holiday would be a boost to business, the economy, jobs and investment. Bernard Donoghue, head of the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions , said another Bank Holiday at the end of September could help the tourism industry repair our balance sheets.Do you think another Bank Holiday is needed in September  Let us know in the commentsHe also said it would be the ideal way to thank the NHS and key workers.He told The Independent : We know tourism was hit first, hit hardest and will take the longest to recover.A bank holiday weekend will typically generate  and  per cent of annual income. Losing so many has been really disastrous. To introduce a new Bank Holiday, the Queen - acting on advice of ministers - must make a Royal Proclamation.  This was most recently done in  to mark the Diamond Jubilee. Hundreds of pubs, bars and restaurants opted to close early on Monday due to the weather.It comes amid growing pressure on Boris Johnson to speed up the next stage of the roadmap, which would see people in England allowed inside pubs and restaurants from May .The last two Septembers, meanwhile, have seen a late surge of summer weather, giving industry bosses confidence their back-up plan wonapost also be hit with bad weather. Alastair Kerr, who spearheads the Campaign for Pubs, told MailOnline: We believe that the Government should have put in a contingency plan in place, to allow pubs to open up their inside areas instead, however it did not happen and as such many pubs remained closed on Monday.Pubs have faced the worst  months of trading in their history and as such missed many Bank Holiday trading days. Any opportunity to regain a Bank Holiday would be welcomed by many in the hospitality sector, as for many pubs, it is a well needed economic boost in quieter times.
