title: polling stations open for scottish elections
story: Polling stations across Shetland opened at am this morningfor the Scottish parliamentary elections.Thirty-four polling stations will be open until pm tonight for physical votes, with six candidates standing for the Shetland constituency seat.Standing for the seat are: Beatrice Wishart , Tom Wills , Martin Kerr , Nick Tulloch , Brian Nugentand Peter Tait .The largest polling place is the Clickimin in Lerwick, for , voters, while the smallest is the Uyeasound Public Hall in Unst .The total electorate in the isles is , voters, with , already using a postal vote before today.Counting of the ballot papers will start at the Clickimin at .am on Friday, th May, with the final result expected at around pm...The SIC says it has taken steps to make polling stations as safe as possible as final preparations are made for Thursday#s Scottish elections. Across#Demand responsive bus services, bike pools and car sharing are some of the ideas being considered for the future of transport in Shetland.Demolition work is set to get underway on the first stage on the Knab redevelopment project next week.Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: snp pledge 50000 island incentive as stark population projections are
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn its Scottish Parliament election manesto the SNP said the bonds will support people to buy homes, start businesses and otherwise make their lives for the long-term in these communities.The party have also pledged to give local authorities powers to manage the numbers of second homes in their area and work with Community Land Scotland to find land for more housing. from across the Highlands and Islands have signed an open letter seeking drastic action from local and national politicians amid an “existential crisis” caused by rising house prices, a dearth of sustainable work and an increase in holiday let properties.The SNP’s election manesto states: #To help stem depopulation, we will establish an Islands Bond # offering  bonds of up to £, to young people and families to stay or move to islands currently threatened by depopulation.#The bonds will support people to buy homes, start businesses and otherwise make their lives for the long-term in these communities.“It goes on to add: #To stop depopulation and support our communities, we will give local authorities the powers to manage the numbers of second homes in their area and we will work with Community Land Scotland so we can find the right land to deliver more housing in our rural areas.#Information on population estimates for  published by the Comhairle nan Eilean Siar highlighted a decrease of . per cent from mid  to mid  giving the Outer Hebrides an estimated population of ,.The median age in the islands was estimated to be . years in June  # which is more than seven years older than the average for Scotland as whole .Meanwhile, predictions from the National Records of Scotland suggest that the total population of the Outer Hebrides will fall to , by  # which represents a projected decline of  per cent or , people within that period.The equivalent figure for Scotland is projected to increase by . per cent.Moreover, in the period from  to  the Outer Hebrides it expected to see a . per cent decline in population, while the working age population #  years and over # is projected to decline by six percent.By contrast, it is projected to have a  per cent increase in those aged  and over by .While the chronic lack of affordable and available housing in many communities across the west Highlands and Islands has been a long-standing issue it has recently been placed front and centre of the political agenda ahead of Scottish Parliament Elections on th May.Indeed, across the last few weeks, the Free Press has reported on how young people are being acutely effected.The new movement Iomairt an Eilein has been spearheaded by nine campaigners originally from Skye, some of are currently based outwith the island having felt that they have been priced out of moving back home to work and live.Additionally, the Free Press has heard first-hand this week of the obstacles facing a young award-winning graduate seeking to move home to Lewis from Glasgow with his partner to live and develop his business.In terms of the outlook for the Highlands, the National Records of Scotland project the region’s population to increase by . per cent over the -year period between  and  from , to ,. However, the - age group is expected to drop by . per cent, while the - will experience an increase of . per cent.The corresponding figures for the decade between  and  highlight a drastic decline of . per cent in the  to  age group in the Highlands, while the  and over age group increased by . per cent.

title: tourism debate election hopefuls to take part in skye
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe focus will be on the recovery and development of tourism on Skye but any question that directly relates to issues affecting the island will be acceptable.The event, to be led by SkyeConnect chairman Dave Till, will allow people to submit questions in advance to the four candidates for the Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch constituency # John Erskine , Kate Forbes , Jamie Halcro Johnstonand Denis Rixson .During the -minute hustings candidates will be given two minutes each to make their pitch to voters. website. Questions can be submitted in advance to info@skye-connect

title: london developer wants to build 16 family homes on
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineCharles Garton Jones, a London-based property developer who also owns the Cow Shed boutique bunkhouse in Uig, is aiming to build the detached houses next to his Bracken Hide Hotel, off Struan Road. he hopes to provide the homes with an ultrafast broadband connection free of charge for the first five years.He said: “We have applied for  three-bedroom houses, and five four-bedroom houses. They are all on generous plots with good-sized gardens. The site is circa five acres, so we are looking at about three houses per acre.“The houses are entirely within the local plan site which is allocated for housing with an indicative housing capacity of  houses.”When asked what his motivation was for building, he said: “I think Skye post-pandemic is a good market for detached houses, but what we are trying to do is build homes with accessibility to schools and Portree itself.” sought to establish how much the homes would actually cost.Mr Garton Jones said: “We haven#t got that far. Simply because until you have planning permission you don’t have a product.“And the market moves, so a figure now could be out of date in six month’s time. I have been encouraged, though, by the new five per cent deposit mortgages the government are backing. I hope that could be really helpful.“Lenders are also starting to offer mortgages at five and a half times buyers’ earnings as opposed to four or four and a half times, so that will also help with how much people can borrow.”He added: “Because of the proximity to the schools and Portree it is not going to appeal to people who are looking to buy a holiday home. They want to be in the middle of nowhere.“I think it is going to appeal to people who are looking to buy it as their main home and want access to the schools and decent internet so they can work.”As an extra incentive the developer plans to connect all the houses via a full fibre GB broadband connection to the nearby BT exchange.“This connection will be provided by us completely free of charge for the first five years,” he added.“This is possible because the capacity we will have for the hotel is well beyond what we will need. This is still subject to BT surveys, though, but it is a realistic aspiration.”The housing scheme, which Mr Garton Jones describes as “an amalgam of Highland and Scandinavian culture” has been designed by Plockton-based architect Olli Blair, who caught the eye of the developer with his work on the Raasay Distillery building.Mr Garton Jones said he hoped to get on site by September October this year.The Bracken Hide Hotel is scheduled to open in April .If anyone is looking for more information on the homes or to register an interest they can contact Mr Garton Jones via charlie@gartonjones

title: waternish youngsters raise more than 7000 with
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoinePat Matheson from Halistra lost her husband Campbell to the illness, and her family thought it would be a good idea to raise funds for the charity in memory of Campbell and to raise awareness of AMMF. The family would like to extend their gratitude to everyone who helped achieve the remarkable sum in excess of £,.SomhairleRuairidhLexyAbigailRoganEoghainnMaraand Tobihad aimed to cycle a total of  miles to raise funds for AMMF. But on Saturday the th of March, which would have been their Seanair’s birthday, most of them cycled from Fairy Bridge to their Granny’s house and smashed their target – clocking up over  miles between them in high winds, rain, sleet and hailstones.

title: lifeboat mission leaves portree crew member in a
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineRNLI volunteers have been sharing some of the stranger situations they have found themselves in when their pagers go off to herald the lesaving charity’s Mayday Mile appeal.Iain Beaton, a member of Portree leboat, was enjoying that post-lockdown highlight, a trip to the hairdresser, when his pager sounded one day last summer.Iain, a builder who has  years’ leboat service in two separate stints, said: “I hadn’t had a haircut in months and I was desperately looking forward to it. I had not long sat down in the salon in Portree and was getting my hair washed when my pager went off.“I just sprinted out the door with the cape still on and my head full of shampoo – you don’t think when you get a shout, you just go. Morven the hairdresser didn’t know what had happened and I certainly got a lot of funny looks running down the pier!“We went to the aid of two women who had got cut off by the tide at the back of Raasay, and they kept looking at me. Needless to say I got endless ribbing from the crew. I’m just glad Morven hadn’t started cutting or I would have looked even stranger. Morven came up to the house the next day so I did eventually get that haircut.”The RNLI is preparing for a busy summer with more families than ever expected to opt for holidays in the UK because of the pandemic. Many of them will be heading to the coast.To keep lesavers kitted out and trained it has launched the Mayday Mile which encourages folk to cover a one-mile distance, be it walking, running, swimming, skating or cycling, to help raise funds. and find out how to make a donation or hold a socially-distanced sponsored event.

title: editorial kennedy commitment would be a fitting cause for political
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIt was his seventh in a row as a Highland member of parliament and with a majority of more than , in Ross, Skye and Lochaber it seemed then that his seat was secure for as long as he wanted it.Yeta week is a long time in politics, the last decade has proved aeonic.The General Election of May  brought an end to the UK’s  years of centre-left dominance, and it was to prove the first in a series of seismic polls which tore up the psephologist’s rule book.The  election gave the Liberal Democrats a taste of power in an unlikely coalition with the Tories, but it has been electoral oblivion for them ever since – including in their former Highland heartlands.A year later the SNP romped to a majority in a Scottish parliament that had been designed to prevent any one party having overall control. In so doing the path was paved toward an independence referendum which eventually maintained the -year-old Union, but still served to elevate the question to become the defining Scottish issue of our times.– was Charles Kennedy’s.A few weeks later the affable Abrach was dead, aged just .The turbulent, and increasingly polarised times continued as a Brexit referendum was granted, and the UK – in spite of all major parties backing remain – voted to leave the EU in . There followed four years of painful negotiation Theresa May was anointed, became a lame duck, and departed as PM to be replaced by Boris Johnson.Johnson saw off Jeremy Corbyn and ‘got Brexit done’ as he said he would, but post-Covid he might yet be done for himself. As rumours rage that in preference to lockdown he said he would tolerate a virus # from which he almost died # spreading so severely that bodies could “pile high on the streets”, there is a growing sense that the public reckoning he has long escaped may finally be in sight.Meanwhile in Scotland, having survived the ugly fall-out from of an investigation into the handling of sexual harassment complaints against her predecessor and political mentor Alex Salmond, Nicola Sturgeon remains odds-on to become First Minister again in  # perhaps even with the overall majority she was unable to secure in .Whether victory leads to a second referendum depends not only on next week’s result but on whose ‘rights’ will take precedence in the eyes of the UK government who by law would need to sanction another vote.Because inescapably it is Covid-, how it is tackled and treated, and how we can recover as a country from it, that is the major issue facing all of us.It seems lamentable that, amid the constitutional flux and an increasing entrenchment of views, that there has been so little sign of a consensual approach – between both governments and parties # to steer the country away from the crisis.And that brings us back to the original point about the late Charles Kennedy.The landscape which he occupied has altered beyond recognition, but has changed politics meant better politics or brought improved outcomes  The jury is out, and it is a question voters should consider as they head for the booths.’ brought some encouraging news.Having seen the treatment Mr Kennedy received back in , the LibDems have called for a “a zero-tolerance approach to abuse and to lead a respectful campaign”.Their pledge calls for derogatory, untrue, or hateful messages on social media to be publicly denounced and challenged to treat political opponents and journalists with respect, and to run an honest campaign.The SNP, Tories, Labour and Greens – all of whom have members who have experienced threats and abuse in ious forms – have all signed up.It would be a fitting tribute to Charles Kennedythis is one electoral promise they can work together and fulfil.

title: highland locations connect to 4g for the first time thanks to
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine: EEPartnering with the Scottish Government, the Home Office and WHP Telecoms, EE has connected locations, including Tarskavaigand Glencripesdale to its high-speed G network, with Killilanand Polbaindue to be connected this summer.These sites are part of the Scottish Government’s £ million Scottish G Infill programmewhich is anticipated to deliver up to  masts to so-called ‘not spots’ in rural Scotland – including those being used by EE as part of the Emergency Services Network roll-out.Along with these sites, EE will extend G in a further  areas across the country, including to Dalwhinnie and Nairn, by the end of  as part of the Shared Rural Network Initiative, boosting connectivity in rural Scotland. The programme is run by the UK’s four mobile network operators and the UK Government to extend G coverage to % of the UK’s geography by the middle of this decade.Jane Wood, BT Group Scotland director, said: “Extending the network will offer a much-needed leline to families and businesses impacted by the ongoing pandemic, as many are working from home and keeping in touch with family and friends via digital technology.”Martyn Cheyne, WHP strategic development director, said: “WHP Telecoms is pleased to have facilitated this reliable coverage by providing robust, future-proofed infrastructure from which EE is now delivering G coverage. We welcome other operators to share this site to reduce the amount of infrastructure required in the landscape, increasing coverage and choice for everyone.”

title: cases of india variant confirmed in ni
story: The Department of Health has been notied by the Public Health Agency of seven confirmed cases of the VUI B...Coronavirus iant in Northern Ireland.These are the first confirmed cases of this iant in the province.The Department of Health is working closely with the PHA and the Regional Virology Laboratory in relation to the investigation and assessment of these cases.Incident management protocols have been activated. A detailed health protection risk assessment will be part of the public health response, as will contact tracing.Chief Medical Officer Dr Michael McBride said: “This news is not entirely unexpected and plans are in place for such an eventuality.“While preventative measures – including travel restrictions – are very important, the assessment is that these will delay rather than permanently prevent the spread of iants already detected where on these islands.“Confirmation of these cases does not mean this iant is going to become the most prevalent or the dominant strain in Northern Ireland.“It does, however, highlight why caution is still essential in relation to COVID-.“The most effective way to stop iants developing or spreading is to keep pushing down infection rates and transmission of the virus in our community.“All iants spread in the same way. We protect ourselves and others by following public health advice and getting vaccinated when our turn comes.“Social distancing and limiting the number of contacts we have are still vitally important. So too are wearing a face covering and washing hands well and often. Also, please always remember the particular risks from indoor settings, especially those that are crowded and have poor ventilation.”

title: fenaghy road surface scheme ready to start
story: A pound, resurfacing scheme for Fenaghy Road, Cullybackey will commence on Monday  May .The scheme extends from Main Street Cullybackey for approximately . kilometres to Galgorm Spa and Resort and is expected to be completed by Friday  June .To facilitate the works it will be necessary to introduce a full road closure on Fenaghy Road, Monday to Friday from .am to .pm for the duration of the works and also on Sunday  May. During these times a ersion will be in operation via Sand Road Woodtown Road Ballymena Road and vice versa.The Department has programmed the work operations and traffic management arrangements to minimise inconvenience, however, road users should expect some delays and are advised to allow additional time when travelling in the area.In order to help ensure the safety of road users and road workers the public is asked to comply with all temporary traffic restrictions and to drive with extra care when travelling in the vicinity of the works.The dates and duration of the works will be dependent on the progress of the scheme and on favourable weather conditions. All work will be carried out in line with current public health and safety advice with safe systems of working in place for staff and contractors.For more information about this and other improvement schemes visit: www.TrafficwatchNIMinister Mallon said:“This signicant investment will greatly improve the strength and surface quality of this section of the road network. This will benefit all who use it including businesses and residents in the area. I would like to thank the travelling public and local residents in advance for their cooperation while these much needed works are completed.”

title: seth raises 1340 for great cause
story: A Ballymena teenager has raised more than pound for Macmillan Cancer Support after completing a half marathon at the weekend. Seth Parkis a Year  pupil at Ballymena Academy and is keen on rugby, football, golf and hockey.During lockdown he decided to keep himself fit by training for the Belfast half marathon. For  weeks Seth was pounding the roads to build his fitness and all that hard training paid idends at the weekend when he completed his run.He originally set out to raise poundbut his efforts save seen him race past that target with the current total sitting at at pound!You can help raise money for this great cause by donating directly to the fundraising page www.justgiving Seth-Park.JustGiving sends your donation straight to Macmillan Cancer Support and automatically reclaims Gt Aidyou are a UK taxpayer, so your donation is worth even more.

Picture By: Arthur Allison Pacemaker Press.Centenary Poll age chartCentenary Poll age chartCentenary Poll: Male and female identitiesCentenary Poll chartCentenary Poll chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueOverall, the exclusive Belfast -Kantar poll shows a third of all people living in Northern Ireland now consider themselves Northern Irish. Picture By: Arthur Allison Pacemaker Press.Gareth CrossTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailBritish identity is on the decline in Northern Ireland with more and more younger people identying as Northern Irish, a poll reveals today.While % of over-s here consider themselves British, just % of those aged - feel the same way.There is a less notable rise in those considering themselves Irish - % of those aged + identy as Irish, compared with % aged between  and .The - age group has the highest percentage of people identying as Irish and Northern Irish, with the lowest who identy as British.There is a huge drop off in those who consider themselves British between the - age groupand those aged - Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll age chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll age chartOverall, the exclusive Belfast -Kantar poll shows a third of all people living in Northern Ireland now consider themselves Northern Irish.One-thirdalso consider themselves British, % are Irish, with the rest either not saying or unsure.Read MoreSarah Creighton:OpinionWe want to define ourselves outside orange and green boundaries that labelled our parents in pastAllison Morris:OpinionPracticalities will trump identity and ideology in any Irish Unity referendumJim Gracey:OpinionThose behind All Ireland football team don’t understand the psyche of fansAmong young people aged - the number of people who see themselves as Northern Irish hits a high of %. By contrast only % of those aged + declare as Northern Irish.The findings emerge on the day that Northern Ireland marks its centenary.They suggest the region has moved away from its traditional orange and green binary definitions and now has a distinct third group.Recent elections have also seen gains by the Alliance Party, which aims to attract support from across the two communities.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll age chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll age chartIn a sign of the demographic shts, the number of people identying as Northern Irish is particularly high among younger age groups, with young people perhaps looking to shy away from the debates of the past.The all-island Kantar poll was commissioned in association with the Sunday Le, Irish Independent and Sunday Independent.It has also examined support for a border poll and a united Ireland, and concerns around the implications for health and wealthpartition was removed.The latest findings examine how respondents identied themselves.Under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement, people born in Northern Ireland are free to identy as British, Irish, both or neither. They are also entitled to hold British and Irish citizenship and passports.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll: Male and female identities FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll: Male and female identitiesMencurrently identy considerably more as British than women , with womenmore likely to feel Northern Irish than their male counterparts .In terms of the Irish identity, % of women said it best describes them, and % of men.The majority of Protestants identy as Britishand Catholics as Irish . Of Protestants, % feel Northern Irish as opposed to % of Catholics.A tiny numberof Protestants identy as Irish, with % of Catholics saying they are British.People from other religious backgrounds are much more likely to feel Britishthan Irish , while mostconsider themselves Northern Irish.Predictably the majority of unionists loyalists consider themselves British , with % declaring as Northern Irish and % Irish.Among nationalists and republicans % report being Irish, % Northern Irish and % British. Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll chartThe majority of those belonging to neither community consider themselves Northern Irish , with % British and % Irish.In Belfast city, identities are split fairly evenly between Irish , Britishand Northern Irish , reflecting the political ision within the area.In Greater Belfast the majority of people feel either Britishor Northern Irish , with % identying as Irish.The Irish identity is the most popular in the rest of Northern Ireland , with Northern Irishbeing more popular than British .Other findings of the poll showed that % of people in Northern Ireland would consider their political affiliation to be unionist and loyalist as opposed to % for nationalists and republicans.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll chartWith % saying their politics are neither, it reflects the identication results in suggesting Northern Ireland is now split into three groups.Groups with the highest number of people who consider their politics to be neither unionist or nationalist include young people aged -, those with no religion and those who consider themselves Northern Irish.The poll also found that most people in Northern Irelandstill opt for a British passport over an Irish one .Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic title: closing dates for northern ireland debenhams stores revealed
story: Shutting down: Debenhams store in Belfast Photo:Stephen Hamilton FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueShutting down: Debenhams store in Belfast Photo:Stephen HamiltonChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe remaining Debenhams stores in Northern Ireland are set to shut for the final time later in May, after the company confirmed the official dates of closure.Debenhams announced the remaining  stores will close on  May and  May, after previous closing dates were announced last week.The Debenhams store in Ballymena will close on  May, while Belfast’s Castecourt will close its Debenham store on  May.The stores in Newry’s Quays shopping centre and Rushmere shopping centre in Craigavon will also close on  May.The retail giant collapsed into administration last year and reopened its physical stores after lockdown only to sell off its remaining stock.Some , workers in total within the company are losing their jobs, after efforts rescue the ailing store chain failed at the end of last year.Debenhams# Northern Ireland stores had been in lockdown for the first four months  due to Covid restrictions, but they were allowed to reopen along with other non-essential shops on  April.In a statement announcing closure dates for its remaining UK stores, a company spokesperson said: Over the next  days, Debenhams will close its doors on the high street for the final time in its -year history.Our sincere thanks go out to all of our colleagues and customers who have joined us on this journey.We hope to see you all one last time in stores before we say a final goodbye to the UK high street.Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn Picture Martin McKeown.The former Barrack Masters House in Ebrington, Derry. Picture Martin McKeownSDLP MLA Sinead McLaughlin FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEbrington Sqaure in Derry. Picture Martin McKeown.Donna DeeneyTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe failure to fully develop two prime sites gted to Londonderry by the Ministry of Defence almost  years ago is down to a lack of government interest, an MLA has said.Earlier this week, it was announced that a military canteen in Ebrington Square was to get a new lease of le as a restaurant.Derry City and Strabane District Council’s planning committee approved works for ‘Building ’ to be transformed into a bar and restaurant with landscaping and associated works.But Foyle MLA Sinead McLaughlin said progress at Ebrington and Fort George had been too slow, and blamed a lack of government interest in seeing both sites reach their full potential.She has raised the matter with the Executive Office and the Department for Communities, which are responsible for the development of the two former Army bases.The development of Ebrington, which was used as barracks, was initially under the remit of a dedicated company, Ilex, but was later ed to the portfolio of the Office of the First and Deputy First Minister, now the Executive Office.This was because of a perceived lack of progress in developing key projects for Ebrington, such as a maritime museum announced by Ilex in .A planning application for a maritime museum and archive was lodged last month by the Department for Infrastructure.Permission to transform a key building at Ebrington into office space was also approved last month.But Ms McLauglin hit out at the slow progress made over almost two decades.She said: It is now  years since the British Government agreed to transfer the sites to the people of Derry and  years since that transfer happened. Yet both sites are nowhere near where they should be.While parts of Ebrington are now occupied and other buildings are being renovated, there is no excuse for how slow this has been.Ebrington has been held back for several reasons. At its heart, I do not believe that the Executive Office, and its predecessor, the Office of the First Minister and Deputy First Minister, have treated the site as a priority.Capital funding was drip-fed, slowing down progress by years. This was a failure of political leadership that has treated the people of Derry with contempt.Ebrington was supposed to be a project that would turn around Derry#s economy, yet after  years we are still waiting to see it properly realised.Across the River Foyle at Fort George, another prime riverfront location, signs of development are not immediately obvious, with a large office block being the sole occupant.In March, the Department for Communities agreed a £million health hub could be located at Fort George. No start date for this project has been announced.Ms McLauglin said the development of Fort George was even more lacking than Ebrington.She added: Fort George is in an even worse situation. After  years, it is mostly empty. It is likely to be several more years before the proposed new health campus is built.There is a consistent story here, which is that despite Derry having the worst job statistics in Northern Ireland, the Government fails to treat Derry as a priority. In practice, it is a policy of #Derry can wait#.The Executive Office and Department for Communities were contacted for comment.Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor title: nominations closed for dup leadership contestbut party remains silent
story: The final list of candidates put forward for leader and deputy leader positions remains unclear"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ad .ece AUTOCROP w pootsdonaldson.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ad .ece AUTOCROP w pootsdonaldson.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ad .ece AUTOCROP w pootsdonaldson.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ad .ece AUTOCROP w pootsdonaldson.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "Edwin Poots and Sir Jeffrey Donaldson have publicly put their names forward for the role of DUP leader.  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEdwin Poots and Sir Jeffrey Donaldson have publicly put their names forward for the role of DUP leader. Ralph HewittTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe DUP have remained tight-lipped as nominations closed for a new party leader and deputy leader on Thursday.Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots and Sir Jeffrey Donaldson MP have both launched their bids to succeed Arlene Foster.It is unclear who has put their name forward for deputy leader after Lord Nigel Dodds said he would not bid to remain in the role after holding the position for  years.Mrs Foster said she would resign as DUP leader on May  and as First Minister at the end of June.The electoral college is made up of the party’s MPs and MLAs and they will vote for their new leader on Friday, May .In order to become party leader, a candidate must secure the support of at least  of the DUP’s MLAs and MPs.The DUP has been approached for comment on who has put their names forward for the roles.The deadline for nominations was pm on Thursday.Lagan Valley MLA Mr Poots sent a four-page document to his party colleagues telling them thathe becomes leader, he will aim to “restore the party’s fortunes and rebuild unionism”.He added that he will restructure and re-energise the DUP as he confirmed that he will split the jobs of First Minister and party leader.Meanwhile, Sir Jeffrey said he wanted to rebuild a “shared future for Northern Ireland” during his campaign launch in Belfast on Monday.It comes after the News Letter reported that the party has issued a gagging order on both Mr Poots and Sir Jeffrey, banning them from speaking to the media in the run up to the internal elections.It is the first leadership contest in the DUP’s -year history.The gagging order was issued by the DUP press office on Tuesday and stated that party officers had decided that “no candidate is to be fielded by the party for media appearances interview during the period of the leadership during the period of the leadership campaign”.“This applies to both candidates for leader and deputy leader positions,” continued the guidance note.It continued: “No candidate is to unilaterally give broadcast or print interviews about their candidature.”Other party representatives are still permitted to speak to the media but have been advised not to commentate on a preferred candidate or any campaign.Explaining why leader and deputy leader candidates cannot speak to the media, a spokesperson for the DUP stated: “The party officers have taken decisions as to the processes for the election campaign, including the fact that candidates will not be fielded by the party for media opportunities during this time.“Candidates, rather than the apparatus of the party, will continue to promote themselves to the electoral college at this time.“All candidates who have thus far publicly indicated their intention to run have been advised of the details of these matters.”Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn to colleaguesRevealed: the BBC NI title: number on furlough drops below 100000 in
story: richard ramsey FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truerichard ramseyChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThere are now , furloughed jobs in Northern Ireland - down from a recent high of ,.The latest figures from HMRC reflect the recent moves to reopen the economy, with people in industries including hospitality and close contact services being taken off furlough to prepare for reopening.Figures peaked at , in mid-January before falling to , at the end of March - the latest date for which stats are available.The Coronavirus Job Retention Schemeruns until September.The scheme pays up to % of an employee#s salary, up to a maximum of £, a month.Newry, Mourne and Down and Causeway Coast and Glens had the highest take-up rates of the scheme at %.In Northern Ireland and the West Midlands, the wholesale and retail sector had the highest number of employees on furlough at  February, followed by accommodation and food services.Responding to the latest figures, Richard Ramsey, chief economist at Ulster Bank sounded a note of caution.“Northern Ireland’s unemployment rate has been kept articially low due to the arrival of the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme last year,” he said.“The second quarter should see a rapid descent in the number of employments furloughed with a progressive easing of lockdown restrictions at the end of April and again in late May.“The reopening of non-essential retail and the hospitality sector is expected to lead to a similar fall in furloughed employment that occurred last August and September.“Perhaps of more concern is the scale of furloughed employment within the manufacturing sector. This is arguably one of the least affected sectors from the ious lockdown restrictions.“Only  manufacturing jobs came off furlough in March relative to the previous month. That means a sizeable , jobs within manufacturing, or  in  of all jobs, are currently out of action.“The concern is that a signicant number of these jobs may be lost when the furlough scheme expires. That worry is not just confined to manufacturing but to other sectors too.“The lting of lockdown restrictions removes just one barrier to ato employment for many of these furloughed jobs.“However, the even bigger hurdle is will the businesses employing them still be viable ”Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and workExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDetails of external work by BBC staff has been published.BBC reporter Mark Simpsonmark carruthersdeclan harveybarra bestmark simpsonjohn campbellemily maitliss FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDetails of external work by BBC staff has been published.Lauren HarteTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBarra Best, Mark Simpson and Declan Harvey are some of the big-name BBC presenters paid the most for outside work, a new register has revealed.For the first time, news and current affairs presenters must declare their earnings outside of the BBC for engagements including speaking and corporate events.The public service broadcaster announced last October that it would be publishing a quarterly summary of the paid-for external events undertaken by on-air staff “in order to promote the highest standards of impartiality”.Of the seven BBC Northern Ireland staff paid for external events since the start of the year, reporter Mark Simpson topped the list with four appearances.The corporation’s former Ireland correspondent hosted and chaired an event for Newry Chamber of Trade on February , followed by three other events the following month — for Intertrade Ireland on March , the Northern Ireland Hotels Federation on March  and the Dundalk and Newry chambers of trade the following day.According to the declaration published by the BBC, for each of the four external events he received a fee of up to £,.Also in demand was BBC NI economics and business editor John Campbell. He was a  chair for the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce on February  and a list at an event at Queen’s University in Belfast on March .Both of these were in the earnings bracket of up to £,.Also listed is BBC NI weatherman and presenter Barra Best, who hosted an event for Charter NI and the Short Strand Community Forum on February . He received a fee under £,, as did his colleague and Radio Ulster presenter and producer Nicola Weir when she chaired a  for Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon City Council on February .Business correspondent Clodagh Rice was listed for chairing a  for Belfast’s politan Arts Centre on March , while political journalist and presenter Mark Carruthers hosted an event for the Northern Ireland Bureau in Washington on March .BBC Radio Ulster’s Evening Extra presenter Declan Harvey hosted an event for Bryson on March .All of the above were also in the less than £, category.Across the network, Radio  Today presenter Justin Webb, who earns more than £, at the BBC, appears most often in the “£, or above” tier for speaking or hosting events for the Chartered Institute for Securities  Investment, City Wealth Magazine, management consultancy Proxima and the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.Newsnight presenter Emily Maitlis earned more than £, for hosting an event for commercial law firm Mason Hayes and Curran on top of her £, BBC salary, while fellow host Kirsty Wark is recorded in the category as a moderator for the WISH Foundation for Global Health.Veteran presenter Andrew Marr, who earns £,, also received over £, for hosting an event for investment management firm Brewin Dolphin.Today presenter Mishal Husain registered a £,-plus payment from World , while BBC Breakfast’s Naga Munchetty received less than £, to interview a guest for online events company Fane.The engagements registered are for Zoom and webinar appearances, with live conferences still not permitted under Covid- restrictions.The BBC said around % of all appearances, which include full-time and part-time staff, were for a fee below £,, with % of these under £,.Staff must seek written approval from a isional head of department before signing up to any external engagements.A BBC spokesman said: “The BBC’s robust and longstanding editorial guidelines permit staff to carry out additional engagements as long as they do not compromise the integrity or impartiality of the BBC.“The register was announced last October and launched in January as part of a series of measures to ensure the highest standards of impartiality across the organisation. New staff guidance on impartiality and social media use was published last year and new impartiality training was rolled out in January.”Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic title: seven confirmed cases of covid 19 indian variant detected in
story: Dr Michael McBride FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDr Michael McBrideChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailSeven confirmed cases of the so-called Indian coronavirus iant have been detected in Northern Ireland, according to the Department of Health.The department said they had been notied by the Public Health Agency of what is known as the VUI B...iant.The Department of Health said they are working closely with the PHA and Regional Virology Laboratory to investigate the cases further.Describing it as “note entirely unexpected”, the chief medical officer Dr Michael McBride confirmed “plans are in place” to deal with the presence of the iant.The Department of Health has been notied by the Public Health Agency of seven confirmed cases of the VUI B...Coronavirus iant in Northern Ireland.â¡ï¸https:t.co UKlYHtTGI pic zwaeoiEBN— Department of HealthMay , “While preventative measures – including travel restrictions – are very important, the assessment is that these will delay rather than permanently prevent the spread of iants already detected where on these islands,” he said.“Confirmation of these cases does not mean this iant is going to become the most prevalent or the dominant strain in Northern Ireland.“It does, however, highlight why caution is still essential in relation to Covid-.“The most effective way to stop iants developing or spreading is to keep pushing down infection rates and transmission of the virus in our community.“All iants spread in the same way. We protect ourselves and others by following public health advice and getting vaccinated when our turn comes.“Social distancing and limiting the number of contacts we have are still vitally important. So too are wearing a face covering and washing hands well and often.“Also, please always remember the particular risks from indoor settings, especially those that are crowded and have poor ventilation.”The Indian iant of Covid- has been detected in other parts of the UK and the Republic of Ireland.Health officials in London suggest almost % of coronavirus cases there now relate to the iant, while eight cases of the iant were detected in the Republic of Ireland last month.Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoIn Focus:WeekendCoronavirusBelfast BeatNewsletter sign-upBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumCentenary poll: Health and wealth key issues in Irish unication debateSuzanne BreenExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseEconomic recovery of the UK and Republic is key to the unity debate FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEconomic recovery of the UK and Republic is key to the unity debateMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailDebate on a border poll has so far focused largely on flags and anthems, but our survey suggests that health and wealth are key issues on which a referendum on Irish unity will succeed or fail.The future health system and taxes matter at least as much to people as what happens the Tricolour and Amhrán na bhFiann.The DUP would do well to focus on these findings as it chooses its future leader. Read MoreCentenary poll: % in Northern Ireland want referendum but would not accept higher taxes to fund reunicationCentenary poll suggests only % of people in Northern Ireland consider Irish language to be importantEsmond Birnie:OpinionOur economy needs recuperation, not a constitutional shockThe Union would be better served by making strong economic arguments for its preservation, rather than politicians heading down the rabbit hole of poking their noses into people#s bedrooms and private lives.Our poll findings suggests that nationalists have a job of work to do to make a strong financial case for a united Ireland, although that is certainly not an impossible task.!fordocument.querySelectortThe Scottish Government produced a -page white paper laying out the case for independence in . There is no sign that a similarly comprehensive blueprint is on the horizon from nationalists here.Our poll indicates that the strongest argument unionists could employ is that Irish unity would hit people in their pockets on both sides of the border.More than half in Northern Ireland think they#d be worse off with just % believing they#d prosper. But % of people were unsure, meaning that the economic arguments on both sides really need to be formed and aired.!fordocument.querySelectortIn the Republic, four in  thought they#d be worse off in a united Ireland, one in five disagreed, and a staggering % didn#t know. If RTE hasn#t already planned it, another Claire Byrne Live to shed light on this part of the debate would be warmly welcomed.A majority on both sides of the border said they wouldn#t be prepared to pay more taxes to fund Irish unity.!fordocument.querySelectortNorthern Ireland currently receives a £bn annual subvention from Westminster. Almost half of people in the Republic said they#d match thator pay some of it . A third were totally opposed to doing so.But the £bn figure is disputed. It#s the UK statistical calculation that encompasses costs which nationalists believe wouldn#t transfer to a new united Ireland. Those costs include UK government debt interest, contributions to the UK armed forces and pension liabilities.!fordocument.querySelectortStill, Northern Ireland#s low cost of living and high number of public sector jobs will be extremely successful weaponsunionists are forced to do battle in a border poll.The jewel in the crown will of course be the NHS. Six in  voters here would be uncomfortable about transferring to the Republic#s health service.Changing it to a system similar to the NHS with free access and no prescription charges would surely be essential for nationalists in a future referendum. The British Treasury footing the bill during the pandemic for the furlough scheme also gives unionists strong ammunition.However, nationalists will be able to use Northern Ireland#s poor infrastructure, low wages, and very small private sector in their arguments. They will also suggest that considerable economic opportunities and potential investment could open up in the event of Irish unity.This poll gives Irish unity campaigners many reasons to pause for thought. Yet it also counters claims made by those who oppose constitutional change. The idea that the south doesn#t want the north is contradicted.More than two-thirds of people in the Republic support Irish unity with just % against.In Northern Ireland, there was a clear pro-Union lead - % to %, with % undecided.Some % of people here want a border poll compared to % opposed in the Republic two-thirds want one. Among referendum supporters, seven in  on both sides of the border want one now or within five years. Those figures suggest that the Taoiseach, who has dragged his feet on the issue and ruled out a border poll in coming years, is out of step with voters.The th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement in  is the date many nationalists are now speaking of for a referendum.The economic recovery of both the UK and the Republic post-pandemic will be key to the unity debate. If one state fares remarkably better than the other that will sway a signicant amount of Northern Ireland voters.Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn to colleaguesRevealed: the BBC NI presenters paid the most for external workFormer Fermanagh businessman James Balmer  charged with historical sexual abuseBobby Sands burial wishes ignored in favour of ‘political beneficial’ Belfast funeralBobby Sands ‘changed his mind’ over Belfast funeral before deathTop VideosPlayWatch: Suzanne Breen gives her take on the DUP leadership racePlayPro-united Ireland poster removed from Divis Tower in Belfast PlayTrial of two veterans accused of IRA leader murder collapsesLatest The CentenaryThree young voices... why I feel Northern Irish, why I feel British and why I feel IrishCentenary poll: Public ided on terror amnesties as pardons for terrorists and troops leave people tornSuzanne BreenOpinionNorthern Ireland#s a powderkeg... but will of people must always prevailCentenary poll: #Irish unity would jeopardise peace in Northern Ireland# - Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoIn Focus:WeekendCoronavirusBelfast BeatNewsletter sign-upBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumOur economy needs recuperation, not a constitutional shockEsmond BirnieExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseA week ago, the London-based Institute for Government confirmed that Northern Ireland receives a sizeable subsidy of more than £bn: we get more back than we pay into the UK tax and public spending systemPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA week ago, the London-based Institute for Government confirmed that Northern Ireland receives a sizeable subsidy of more than £bn: we get more back than we pay into the UK tax and public spending systemMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailUS President Harry Truman once said, How far would Moses have gonehe had taken a poll in Egypt  Usefully, the Kantar Belfastpoll includes some of the practicalities, such as cash and healthcare.A week ago, the London-based Institute for Government confirmed that Northern Ireland receives a sizeable subsidy of more than £bn: we get more back than we pay into the UK tax and public spending system.That fiscal deficit doesn#t necessarily equal the financial cost of a united Ireland, but it is signicant. Those who favour a united Ireland have responded in a number of ways to this situation:Deny the figures - yes, about £bn of the transfer is an attributing to NI of spending done by the UK central government . But, in a united Ireland surely some of such spending would continue Claim taxes could rise - they could, but, as this poll shows, there would be considerable opposition to that, especially in the Republic.Claim public spending in NI could be scaled back - it is one thing to argue our public sector is too large in relative terms, but any sudden adjustment would probably provoke a major recession. Claim a united Ireland could out-grow the problem - true, in recent years the Republic#s economic growth rate has surpassed that in NI, even discounting the tax-avoiding behaviour of multinationals, but can we really assume that unity per se would have a sudden transformative impact on NI#s economic performance Claim that the Dublin government could borrow to keep NI afloat - at the moment, interest rates are very low, but that won#t always be true.Argue that the UK Government would leave its cheque book behind - in the s, the London government wrote off the Irish Free State#s obligation for part of the UK#s public debt, but can we really imagine a UK government being so generous as to wipe out debt and continue to pay for some welfare benefitsand subsidise NI#s infrastructure To be fair, this existence of the big fiscal deficit is also problematic for unionists. They could claim other UK regions have deficits. They do, but none are so large. They could try to argue this is a form of UK solidarity payment, but will that really wash with taxpayers in south-east England The biggest danger is that a long-term dependency on subsidy from Great Britain has actually distorted economic behaviour. As RHI exemplied, free money trumps making necessary reforms.One particularly interesting area of Northern Ireland-Republic comparisons is healthcare: a major focus of the Kantar Belfastpoll.The south uses a mixture of state provision and private insurance. The polling response shows a very strong preferences in NI to continue with the NHS model. That said, the advantages of free at the point of use are blunted by our ening waiting lists.OECD data implies healthcare spending per person in the Republic now exceeds that in NI and the UK average.Of course, as indicated by US experience, very high spending does not necessarily bring better quality. We know the dference in Covid vaccination rates.To finish with a health analogy, for all its points of strength, the NI economy remains in need of intensive care - a period of recuperation, rather than a major constitutional shock is probably the priority.Dr Esmond Birnie is senior economist at Ulster UniversityBelfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn to colleaguesRevealed: the BBC NI presenters paid the most for external workFormer Fermanagh businessman James Balmer  charged with historical sexual abuseBobby Sands burial wishes ignored in favour of ‘political beneficial’ Belfast funeralBobby Sands ‘changed his mind’ over Belfast funeral before deathTop VideosPlayWatch: Suzanne Breen gives her take on the DUP leadership racePlayPro-united Ireland poster removed from Divis Tower in Belfast PlayTrial of two veterans accused of IRA leader murder collapsesLatest The CentenaryThree young voices... why I feel Northern Irish, why I feel British and why I feel IrishCentenary poll: Public ided on terror amnesties as pardons for terrorists and troops leave people tornSuzanne BreenOpinionNorthern Ireland#s a powderkeg... but will of people must always prevailCentenary poll: #Irish unity would jeopardise peace in Northern Ireland# - title: the wedding is coming strabane manrecreatesgots iconic iron throne ahead of his bigday
story: Ryan McDevitt and his fiancee Megan Giblin FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRyan McDevitt and his fiancee Megan GiblinLauren HarteTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA Co Tyrone man has taken Games of Thrones fandom to a whole new level ahead of his wedding this summer.Not content with having GoT-themed invitations, centrepieces and pop-up banners honouring the HBO fantasy series, Ryan McDevitt, from Strabane, has recreated the show’s Iron Throne.The -year-old and his fiancee, Megan Giblin, originally from Lford in Co Donegal, are both huge fans of the show, which was partly filmed in Northern Ireland.They have already had to postpone their wedding twice and are hoping it is third time lucky on July , which is also Megan’s th birthday. Graphic designer Ryan met the part-time dog groomer in  before proposing a year later in front of Disneyland Paris’s Sleeping Beauty Castle.As first reported in the Strabane Chronicle, when he and Megan began planning their wedding and looked into the possibility of renting a photo booth, Ryan instead decided to create his own photo prop.“I’m just a real cheapskate. As the money we were spending started to ratchet up, I just thought I would make it myself,” he told the Belfast .“I have already made all the centrepieces for tables from each of the houses of the Seven Kingdoms, including the Lannisters, Starks and Targaryens.We have done our wedding invites in the theme and there will be pop-up banners. This extra addition was just supposed to be a bit of fun, but now it’s all gone a bit mad.”Thanks to Ryan’s efforts, the wedding guests, whether Games of Thrones fans or not, will have the chance to sit on the iconic Iron Throne and rule like a king or queen of Westeros,only for a few moments.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseRyan McDevitt on the Iron Throne he built for his wedding in July FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRyan McDevitt on the Iron Throne he built for his wedding in JulyIn the land of Westeros, the Iron throne was made by Aegon Targaryen, the first king of the Seven Kingdoms, from swords surrendered by his enemies.According to the show’s lore, the throne was made from , swords over  days. Spikes and jagged edges in every direction make it one very intimidating seat.In Ryan’s case, he had to make do with plastic swords purchased from the internet. “I went to loads of charity shops in search of the right chair and finally came across a really old-fashioned one, like what you see in your granny’s house,” he said.“I ripped all the cushion off the chair, stripped it down to the bare bones and then built up from the base.I got big sheets of plywood from a building supplier, made a stencil for the back part and worked from there.Then I bought a load of medieval plastic swords from eBay. I got yoga mats too and cut them up to be wrapped around the chair.“I started work on the throne last year, just before Covid hit, and worked on it bit by bit. I’m also planning a Dof Jon Snow’s famous Longclaw sword as another wedding photo prop.”And what about the all-important bride-to-be’s verdict  “I think it’s class,” said Megan. “It’s our wedding, so we may as well go all-out. I had no idea how it would turn out, but it looks amazing. I hope our family and friends think so too.”Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn to colleaguesRevealed: title: barnier detailsstruggleto keep calmduring brexit talkswith dup
story: Former chief EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier. Photo: Olivier Hoslet AP. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFormer chief EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier. Photo: Olivier Hoslet AP.Gareth CrossTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe EU#s chief Brexit Negotiator Michel Barnier has described how he nearly lost his cool with the DUP during discussions about the UK#s withdrawal process.In a new book on Brexit published this week, Mr Barnier said that senior DUP figures regarded him as a puppet of the Irish government during negotiations and alleged that they wanted to use the Brexit process to help prevent a united Ireland.He also expressed frustration at the party#s inflexibility during the negotiations, saying they were unwilling to compromise, but also had no positive solutions of their own to put forward.Mr Barnier said he felt peace in Ireland was vulnerable to the slightest spark amid ongoing dissent over the Northern Ireland Protocol.He also condemned the EU#s threat to trigger Article  of the protocol in a row over vaccine supply#s.“That went directly against our efforts and the responsible attitude we had held during the previous four and a half years, precisely to avoid theof a hard Border in the middle of the island of Ireland, often in the face of British provocations. And these provocations continue, unfortunately, he said.#The Grand Illusion# was published in French on Thursday, with an English language version to follow in the Autumn.In it the former French foreign minister details his diary as the UK and EU worked to reach a withdrawal agreement following the Brexit referendum in .Among his recollections of a myriad of high stakes meetings between - are a number of notable parleys with the DUP.On March   he met with DUP leader Arlene Foster, then MEP Diane Dodds, the party#s Brexit spokesperson Sammy Wilson and advisor Timothy Johnston.Mr Barnier recalled Mrs Dodds took the lead in the meeting, and that left him unsure who held power within the party.He said the DUP accused the EU Commission of being the puppets of Dublin, which they detest, and we would like to create a border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK so as to avoid one in the middle of the island.The EU#s chief negotiator met with Mrs Foster and Mrs Dodds again in October  shortly before then Prime Minister Theresa May reached a deal with the bloc, which was rejected by the House of Commons and DUP MPs.Mr Barnier said he felt of the DUP pair both of them don’t like each other and it shows.He also accused them of preparing exaggerated rhetoric before attending the meeting.Listening to these two women, I had dficulty keeping calm and I wonderedTheresa May will have the courage and will not to give in to their demands. They are opposed to everything, want nothing to do with the concrete proposals we are making, the diplomat recalled.Mr Barnier said he told Mrs Foster and Mrs Dodds: It is your Brexit vote which creates the problem. We are waiting for you to bring forward ideas and proposals. You have produced none. When will you therefore assume the consequences of your own actions However, he is not entirely negative, saying Mrs Dodds was elegant and competent, while Mrs Foster was percise and pragmatic in her questions. He also praised former UUP MEP Jim Nicholson for his sincerity.In the book he admits a fondness for Ireland, noting his work on PEACE funding as EU Commissioner for Regional Policy in the early s.Mr Barnier also recalls how one of his political heroes, legendary French President Charles De Gaulle also enjoyed visits to Ireland, and referenced the  book #Return to Killybegs# by French author Sorj Chalandon, which was inspired by the killing of former Sinn Fein insider turned British agent Denis Donaldson.I promised myself in these negotiations not to give in to controversy or to the attacks from British tabloids, to be careful with language, to stick to the facts, figures, the legal basis, in short not to allow room for emotion or sentiment, for the sake of objectivity, he said.But then, in Ireland, where I recall the terrible pages of the book Return to Killybegs, it is dficult not to be affected by the sensitivity, the emotion of those who express it, the memories which remind me of this tragedy.The DUP has been contacted for a response. Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn to The owner of a Derry cafe will be delivering free turkey dinners with all the trimmings to the needy on Christmas Day.Paula Monk has been running Peggy’s Kitchenin The Old Library Trustin Creggans Central Drive for over a year.Last Christmas she and her business partner Adam Nabaz delivered over  free Christmas dinners and this year they will be doing it all over again.The need in the community this year is greater than ever because of the coronavirus, said Ms Monk. So Ill be in the kitchen prepping on Christmas Eve and then the dinner will be cooked and delivered on Christmas Day for anyone who’s alone or in need of one.Last year we actually had some spare meals left over so I went and delivered them up to the Fire Station, which was the highlight of my Christmas, she said.Paula has been provided with the names of people in the local community who would benefit from the scheme by the Operation Snowball at the OLT and staff at the Long Tower Youth Club.This service is free of charge of course, soyou or someone you know needs help this Christmas please send me a message to the Peggys Kitchen Facebook page,continued Ms Monk. googletag.cmd.push Last year we covered the cost of it ourselves, apart from the desserts, but this year Foyle Fruit have kindly offered to donate the potatoes and vegetables and we have also had donations of containers and cups. All donations are welcome andanyone wishes to help our efforts that help would be much appreciated.Ms Monk has enlisted the help of two delivery drivers to take the food to the Bogside, Brandywell and Creggan areas of the city.Like all cafes, Peggys Kitchen is closed at the moment due to current restrictions.Its sad that we cant open because we really miss our customers like the Over s Club that used to meet here every Wednesday and for a lot of them it was their only source of interaction but the safety of everyone needs to come first, said Ms Monk. googletag.cmd.push We cant wait to reopen again but until then please keep safe.      --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. The Western Trust says that over recent weeks it has been encouraging staff to take the Covid- vaccine. A media briefing was held on Tuesday where the Trust revealed that over  per cent of care home residents have been inoculated. According to Dr Bob Brown, Executive Director of Nursing Primary Care and Older Peoples services, there has also been a ‘very good response’ amongst care home staff. The Trust previously stated that  per cent of care home staff had accepted the vaccine. There are currently no Covid outbreaks in local care homes. The Trust provides care for over , service users in their own homes every day. There has been  per cent vaccine uptake amongst home care staff. googletag.cmd.push Information on vaccine uptake amongst hospital staff and Trust-wide numbers are not available, the meeting heard. Dr Bob Brown, Executive Director of Nursing Primary Care and Older Peoples services in theWestern Trust explained: “I would say that’s not information that we would be providing on the basis that we cannot ask iniduals, have you or have you not had a vaccine,” he explained. “Therefore, we’re working on the basis of exit information. We know we’ve had an increasingly positive uptake but, he said, it’s dficult to provide evidence of specic numbers in each area.” Askedstaff on high-risk hospital wards would be encouraged to take the vaccine, such as those who treat cancer patients, he said: “We’ll certainly use every opportunity we can through our leadership walks to encourage uptake of the vaccine, that’s something as a corporate management team that we have taken as a priority in recent weeks, to absolutely do that.” googletag.cmd.push Chief Executive Dr Anne Kilgallen added: “We continue to have very stringent infection control measures at ward level, continue to have the use of PPE and social distancing as far as possible. “So those measures remain in force and are continually monitored and encouraged by ourselves. “The vaccine is another line of defence but we always will adhere to the very high levels of PPE and infection control at clinical patient contact level.” The prospect of another wave of infections was raised at the media briefing. Geraldine McKay, Director of Acute Hospitals, said there is some data which assures the Trust ‘no high surge’ is anticipated over the summer but a ‘small spike’ could take place at the end of Autumn and beginning of Winter.     She continued: “That would be normal winter pressures and respiratory disease so we’re not surethere would be any additional spike there due to Covid. “That’s the basic information we have at this time.” Dr Kilgallen encouraged the public to take the vaccine and adhere to restrictions to allow the Trust and wider NHS to treat other important health issues. “Take the vaccine when it’s offered but also be aware that restrictions that remain are in our best interests and we should do our best to comply at all times,” she said. ‘VOLUNTARY’ A debate has been ongoing in other parts of the UK about whether the vaccine should be mandatory for care home staff or those working in high-risk areas. The Derry News lodged Freedom of Information requests with the Western Trust, Health and Social Care Board and Department of Health- which oversees the running of the programme - to get a detailed breakdown of vaccine uptake amongst staff. In response, each organisation said it did not hold the information. The DoH explained that thevaccinationprogramme remains voluntary but where uptake is lower than average staff will be ‘encouraged’ to accept the vaccine. A spokesperson said: “As cohorts become eligible, iniduals make their own decisions about stepping forward forvaccination. “The Department does not routinely record reasons why people choose not to bevaccinated. “As the programme proceeds and more information becomes available on uptake rates within particular parts of the HSC workforce, action will be taken to try and encourage uptake in any areas where the uptake levels remains lower than average.” The DoH believes that overall, there has been a ‘good uptake’ of thevaccineamongst health and social care staff. More detailed data will be available in the coming weeks, a spokesperson said. She concluded: “This will enable the Department and Trusts to drill down and obtain more granular data regarding the ious parts of the health service andnecessary focus on those areas with lower uptake rates.”  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A beautul house off the main Derry to Moville has been put up for sale. Bankhead is a modern and luxuriously constructed residence that was built around  with the property incorporating all the modern conveniences. The house has two reception rooms and four large bedrooms with two ensuites. Bankhead is beautully positioned looking over Lough Foyle with approx. . acres of pleasure grounds surrounding the residence. The asking price is €,.  Walking into the property along a wooden elevated gangway bridge with stainless steel into the upper floor there is a practical entrance hall with space and storage for all familyneeds. googletag.cmd.push Once into the house your eyes are immediately drawn towards the expansive water views to the exterior. The kitchen has an impressive island unit that includes an integrated  burner touch top Bora induction hob, integrated extractor and has a breakfast area with seating for four people. There is also remote control blinds in the kitchen and living spaces. The kitchen integrates with the living area seamlessly and the living space which features dual elevations floor to ceiling glazed windows looking over the gardens and grounds with of course the backdrop of Lough Foyle making it truly spectacular.  This space is complete by a wood burning stove making it comfortable in both the winterand indeed the summer. googletag.cmd.push The dining area is perfect for all year family dining with access to the balcony perfect for thosesummer evenings. The upper floor is complete with two bedrooms, one ensuite and family w.c. The ground floor links with the upper floor through a feature staircase with wooden floors. Once downstairs there is a very comfortable family room with stove and patio doors leading to the rear garden and beach. The house links seamlessly with the gardens and pleasure grounds, this being exemplied not only by the abundance of windows offering a plenitude of sunlight but also sliding doors which directly link the living spaces direct to the beautully maintained gardens with the spectacular views.     The gardens and grounds have been landscaped to take advantage of the proximity to the water.    --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Or you can email editor@derrynews.net or editor@derrypost at any time. stickyfirePlace  document.getElementById !   firePlace ! null  googletag.cmd.pushYou are in:  DerryNow  Features JOHN DALLAT: A familys story of coping with grief during pandemicThe former East Derry MLAs daughter Helena marks a year since his passing.The late John Dallat, who passed away a year ago today.Reporter: Helena Dallat ODriscoll::  May   addthis, In memory: Tomorrow marks a year since the death of John Dallat, former Assembly Deputy Speaker and MLA for East Derry. His daughter and SDLP Causeway Coast and Glens councillor, Helena Dallat OrsquoDriscoll, reflects on the past year.Just weeks before my fathers passing, with the COVID death toll rising, Northern Ireland had entered lockdown in a bid to limit the spread of coronavirus. The Health Minister, Robin Swann, had described the potential scale of the impending surge as being of biblical proportions and for the next year, people would live a new normal - no unnecessary journeys, no mixing with other households, working from homepossible and many other restrictions on daily le. Two days after the announcement of the restrictions, we were hit with the news that my father’s cancer treatment had met an unexpected twist and he had weeks to live. googletag.cmd.push Like many families in Northern Ireland, we were to care for and say goodbye to a loved one in lockdown. It is hard to believe that a year has passed since dad died, in some ways time has stood still. I think most families bereaved in the last year will be experiencing a similar feeling. A lack of closure comes with a lockdown death, especiallyrestrictions were at their height. Although a small number of us were privileged to be with dad at the moment he died, we missed the rituals that we had all come to expect as normal. googletag.cmd.push As a society, we have such a respect for the dead and the bereaved, regardless of culture or faith but COVID upended all those customs and comforting gestures. As was the case for many families, we had no wake and we were unable to keep his remains at home. We didn’t carry his coffin. The church was almost empty for his funeral. The only physical touch at his graveside was from our very immediate family. From that moment, I realised that, even as a mum of two tactile daughters, I had totally underestimated physical touch and how it comforts and modulates emotions.     Having no visitors in the months following a death also adds to the feeling of isolation and I have felt particularly for those who might be living in remote areas or who don’t have their families close by.  All things considered, we were one of the luckier families. Although there was a feeling of isolation and loneliness due to the restrictions, at least the conditions were sufficiently safe for us to be with dad at the end. Thanks to first-class medical care from his consultant, our GPs, district nurses, carers and our NI Hospice community hospice nurse, we were able to care for him at home. Our community hospice nurse, in particular, taught us invaluable lessons. We quickly learned about symptom assessment and pain relief but also the preciousness of le and how to let someone with so precious little time left live as fully as possible until the end. He also died with nothing important left unsaid. Many other families never got a chance to nurse or say goodbye to their loved ones because of COVID circumstances and I find that unimaginably heartbreaking. It was a first lesson in just how vital our hospice services are. However, despite their critical nature, their futures are frequently faced with uncertainty. The demands on our palliative and end-of-le care services are steadily increasing but funding has not kept pace. The present funding methodology is flawed and operates without evidence base or up-to-date benchmarks. Last week at Stormont, cross-party support was achieved for the inclusion of death, dying and bereavement in the Programme for Government and I very much welcome that. It is progress but we have a long way to go. We need to give much more sustainable support to our end-of-le care providers. We must not forget that these organisations are lting the burden from the NHS which is why core funding is so important. Given the exceptional nature of this year, there is also a need for additional mental health resources to help deal with COVID’s psychological toll, especially for those grieving in our rural areas and those who have a limited network of support. This pandemic has reminded us that palliative and end-of-le care is a vitally important part of our care system and I believe it has opened up an important conversation around dying and bereavement.  Grief is a normal, albeit sad and challenging, part of le. We will all experience the pain of losing a loved one at some point. However, I believe there is no doubt that the current pandemic has posed unprecedented challenges to the grieving process, setting the stage for more complex and prolonged reactions for many who have lost loved ones. My SDLP colleagues and I will continue to press for more sustainable provision for the dying and bereaved and call for urgent, additional resources to tackle the poor mental health some of our bereaved families are likely to suffer as a result of loss in what have been traumatic conditions.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Or you can email editor@derrynews.net or editor@derrypost at any time.
